pull_request.title: Upgrade Lambda runtime and Terraform module
pull_request.body:
## 🗣 Description ##

This pull request:
- Upgrades the Lambda runtime to Node 16.x
- Upgrades the [`transcend-io/lambda-at-edge/aws` Terraform module](https://registry.terraform.io/modules/transcend-io/lambda-at-edge/aws) to the latest release

## 💭 Motivation and context ##

- The Node 12.x runtime will soon be deprecated, and we were previously on Node 14.x, so jumping to Node 16.x ensures we won't be left twisting in the wind anytime soon
- Updated runtimes are often more efficient, so it makes sense to run on the newest one we can
- Upgrading the Terraform module requires no code changes and does not modify any resources in our case, so it makes sense to stay current.

Note that a Node 18.x runtime is available, but our AWS Terraform provider is too old to support it.

## 🧪 Testing ##

All automated tests pass.  These changes are already deployed to CyHy production.

## ✅ Pre-approval checklist ##

- [x] This PR has an informative and human-readable title.
- [x] Changes are limited to a single goal - *eschew scope creep!*
- [x] All relevant type-of-change labels have been added.
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](../blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] These code changes follow [cisagov code standards](https://github.com/cisagov/development-guide).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass.

commits.body:
Update Lambda@Edge runtime to Node 16.x

Node 18.x is available, but our Terraform AWS provider is too ancient
to support it.

Use the latest release of the transcend-io/lambda-at-edge/aws TF module

This doesn't actually require any changes to our code, nor does it
modify any actual resources, but it's good to stay current.

pull_request.title: Upgrade volumes to gp3 and io2
pull_request.body:
## 🗣 Description ##

This pull request:
- Upgrades volume types to from gp2 to gp3 and from io1 to io2
- Removes the `delete_on_termination` line from the root volume configuration

## 💭 Motivation and context ##

- gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are intertwined with gp2.
- io2 offers 100x more reliability than io1 at the same cost.
- `delete_on_termination = true` is the default, so there is no need to specify it.

## 🧪 Testing ##

@mcdonnnj did a `terraform plan` for the `terraform` directory and verified that all the volume changes would be done in place.

## ✅ Checklist ##

- [x] This PR has an informative and human-readable title.
- [x] Changes are limited to a single goal - _eschew scope creep!_
- [x] All relevant type-of-change labels have been added.
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](../blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] These code changes follow [cisagov code standards](https://github.com/cisagov/development-guide).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass.

commits.body:
Upgrade volumes from gp2 to gp3

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better
performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the
volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are
intertwined with gp2.

Also remove delete_on_termination lines from root volume configs.
delete_on_termination = true is the default, so there is no need to
specify it.

Upgrade volumes from io1 to io2

io2 offers 100x more reliability for the same price.

pull_request.title: Publish the very first revision of these modules
pull_request.body: Definitely not perfect and certainly not done, but far enough along to be called a milestone!

commits.body: Add a first swing at the the modules repo.
Refactor out cloud-init config for masters to support composing multiple files into one script at apply time.
Rename masters module to control_plane.
Allow for a version or channel of k3s to be specified for installation.
Refactor setup, again: this time removing cluster-level dependence on an ALB and setting the state for internal/external DNS zones.
Fix internal DNS conditional and swap control-plane tag from master.
Add target group as an output for the control_plane module.
Remove 'old' version of the endpoint module, make way for regional goodness.
Add the new service_endpoints module that will tentatively support multi-regions.
Add DNS record creation to the service_endpoints module.
Update set identifier to be unique per-region.
Strip away that kinda quirky multi-provider hack.
Refactor control_plane and service_endpoints modules once more, this time to *actually* support multi-region architecture.
Swap the shared_endpoint to using a separate target_group.  We cannot just attach the cluster tg's to the shared_endpoint, as the ALB will route traffic to them even if they have no healthy targets.
Swing all the way back around to using wildcard-based routing for cluster-level endpoints after all.
Finalize on a per-region design for the service module, for now.
Rename service_endpoints to the more accurate shared_endpoint.
Allow ingress ALBs to be specified by name, too.
Update docs substantially, add the option to manage a shared Target Group for each shared_endpoint.
Rehab worker module following changes to control-plane.
Allow for cpu_credits to be set.
Remove references to older dns_zone variables.
Add support for both an external and internal ingress target group, as they can only be attached to one ALB at a time each.
Refactor userdata setup for both clarity and to incorporate a systemd unit so nodes drain and delete themselves from the cluster on shutdown.
Finish up the transition from 'master' to 'control-plane' within the module's resources.
Allow root block device to be customized for both control-plane and worker instances.
Remove old commented-out user_data section.
Clean up cpu_credits spec and port it over to the worker launch template too.
Expand variable descriptions for control-plane and worker nodes.
Update all three modules to allow VPCs and Subnets to either be passed in by ID or looked up, and to allow better lookup filtering.
Revamp the internal/external split of resources to be more re-useable and to support additional types.
Pull in my existing Shared ALB module.
Split out certificate logic into its own module.
Modernize the ALB module to use vars and options now available in other modules.
Allow additional k3s arguments to be specified, add logging to make cloud-init troubleshooting easier.
Begin integrating etcd config into control plane.
Update k3s userdata to match the patterns setup for etcd.
Begin to decouple the workers from requiring a static DNS address, so I can run the control plane in an ASG without paying for an NLB.
Swap control plane over to running in an auto-scaling group.
Pull baseline infrastructure out into its own module.
Rename worker_group module to node_group to align with the latest naming conventions.
Allow etcd version to be configured in terraform.
Tidy up comments and variable descriptions for initial publishing.
Re-expose the target group arns generated in cluster_baseline, and rename the ingress option to be a bit more explicit following the removal of control-plane DNS.
Polish up variables for certificate module and allow the default zone id to be looked up.
Update shared_endpoint module to align with standards set in newer modules.
Give first swing to publishing docs for the shared_endpoint module.
Add a first pass at READMEs for all modules, update variable descriptions.

pull_request.title: Use project_services module and convert to for_each
pull_request.body:
Convert the project_services module to use for_each instead of count,
and use that module in the core project factory.

Remove the var.apis_authority option.

Add to helpers/migrate.py to also convert this project services
migration. The old GSuite migration will still work. To make this
migration work, it needs to read a value from a resource, which means
calling terraform state show, which is slow.

This is heavily blocked by hashicorp/terraform#22301, as the migrate
script fails to state move the instances of count to instances of
for_each without the for_each resource existing first. As it is, the
migrate script fails with this error:
```
Cannot move to
module.my-project.module.project-factory.module.project_services.google_project_service.project_services["cloudbilling.googleapis.com"]:
module.my-project.module.project-factory.module.project_services.google_project_service.project_services
does not exist in the current state.
```

This is also partially blocked by hashicorp/terraform#10462. As this
moved the project services into a module, the depends_on in the
project_service resource block can't be used in the module block because
of this issue. Since the project_id parameter is referencing the
google_project, it might still work correctly.

Resolves #282
comments:
Thanks for working on this!

Quick feedback on migration script:
1. Let's create a new migration script (migrate4.py) for this. The old migration script should be kept for only that version (you can copy the code though).
2. Given hashicorp/terraform#22301, it might be easier to simply `remove` the existing resources (via `terraform state rm` then re-import them).
Thanks, looking good! Just a few more issues.
Thanks for the contribution! The migration worked flawlessly.

commits.body:
Use project_services module and convert to for_each

Convert the project_services module to use for_each instead of count,
and use that module in the core project factory.

Remove the var.apis_authority option.

Add new helpers/migrate4.py script to convert this project services
migration. To make this migration work, it needs to read values from a
resource, which means calling terraform state show, which is slow.

Doing the migrate with a terraform mv command is blocked by
hashicorp/terraform#22301, so the script instead runs state rm and then
import.
Note that after the migrate each resource instance will show
disable_dependent_services and disable_on_destroy need to be set to
true, because as a Terraform state only value, it can't be gotten from
importing. This makes this workaround functional but messy.

This is also partially blocked by hashicorp/terraform#10462. As this
moved the project services into a module, the depends_on in the
project_service resource block can't be used in the module block because
of this issue. Since the project_id parameter is referencing the
google_project, it might still work correctly.

Resolves #282

Use default statefile and fix dependency breakage

With all the features of Terraform 0.12, the migrate script can
completely run off of remote state, so by default the script will let
Terraform use its default state, remote or local. There is an option to
override this for testing or for keeping remote state safe.

Add verbose option to migrate script, which will print the commands
being run even if dryrun is not enabled.

Revert the output var change in product_services, since it's needed for
the dependency graph. However, the old '.*.' operator doesn't work with
for_each, so replace it with a new [for] construct.

pull_request.title: Fixup errors in test-kitchen test coverage
pull_request.body:
When the test-kitchen tests and fixture modules were refactored and different fixtures were broken out for minimal and full suites, some tests were broken but were hidden because those tests were optional - that is, the test groups were disabled when the relevant parameters were unset.

In addition it was assumed that `inspec` would catch some of these errors by requiring certain inspec attributes would be set, but it appears that the version of inspec doesn't error out when required attributes were missing.

This pull request corrects a number of mistakes from string keys used instead of symbols, and passing through variables into outputs so that inspec can access them.

An outstanding question with this pull request is how to test features that require setup that are particularly heavyweight and/or can't be handled by Terraform. The original approach was to make these features optional, and if the module under test had the appropriate variables defined, then we'd test them. However the test failures that this pull request fixes shows that this approach may not be viable in the long term.

We have the following dependencies that are are optional due to non-trivial setup:

- A shared VPC host project
  - Do we want to stand up a new project with a VPC every time we test the `full` suite? Projects are a somewhat limited resource, but not too limited.
- G Suite group management
  - Adding a group to IAM roles is easy, but managing G Suite group membership cannot be done by Terraform - a user has to manually configure the service account running the tests with domain wide delegation.
  - Adding a group to/from IAM roles is easy, but the tests need a test fixture group to work with. We can create a group on the fly, but that'll require domain-wide delegation
- A destination GCS bucket for GCP project usage
  - Creating a bucket is cheap, but the bucket needs to be created within a project. Should we just stand up a fixture project for this and the shared VPC host project?

This pull request doesn't try to solve these problems; if a dependency is missing we'll just skip the respective tests - but I think we'll need to solve this for other modules.
comments: Just the one issue discovered so far.
Just some minor style nits.
LGTM, thanks

commits.body:
Fixup errors in test-kitchen test coverage

When the test-kitchen tests and fixture modules were refactored and
different fixtures were broken out for minimal and full suites, some
tests were broken but were hidden because those tests were optional -
that is, the test groups were disabled when the relevant parameters were
unset.

In addition it was assumed that `inspec` would catch some of these
errors by requiring certain inspec attributes would be set, but it
appears that the version of inspec doesn't error out when required
attributes were missing.

This commit corrects a number of mistakes from string keys used instead
of symbols, and passing through variables into outputs so that inspec
can access them.

Fixes #61.

Add shared VPC configuration to full suite

The `shared_vpc_subnets` parameter is interpolated because the
project-factory module would not wait for a `google_compute_subnetwork`
data source to resolve its `self_link` before attempting to use the value.
Uncomment `shared_vpc` variable in tfvars example

pull_request.title: Remove billing access from legacy account
pull_request.body:
The staff of the Rust Foundation has access to the billing portal on AWS, historically through the legacy account and now through the new root account that consolidates billing. Instead of updating the custom policy to remove deprecated policies, we are going to remove billing access from the legacy altogether since it is no longer required.

Fixes #359

commits.body:
Remove billing access from legacy account

The staff of the Rust Foundation has access to the billing portal on
AWS, historically through the legacy account and now through the new
root account that consolidates billing. Instead of updating the custom
policy to remove deprecated policies, we are going to remove billing
access from the legacy altogether since it is no longer required.

Fixes #359

pull_request.title: Deploy Datadog integration for AWS accounts
pull_request.body:
Datadog provides an interagration for AWS[^1] that makes it easy to automatically monitor most resources in an account. The integration has been deployed to all accounts in our organization.

[^1]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/getting_started/integrations/aws/

commits.body:
Deploy Datadog integration for AWS accounts

Datadog provides an interagration for AWS[^1] that makes it easy to
automatically monitor most resources in an account. The integration has
been deployed to all accounts in our organization.

[^1]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/getting_started/integrations/aws/

Disable monitoring of Lambda functions

Datadog can monitor Lambda functions, but charges a fee for each
function. This is quite expensive for us, since every routing function
we use in CloudFront is globally distributed and is billed multiple
times (once per region).

For now, we are just going to disable the Lambda integration. Later, we
might want to enable it again, but add a tag and filter to selectively
monitor specific functions.

pull_request.title: Rewrite URLs with plus character for crates.io
pull_request.body:
The CDNs for `static.crates.io` now rewrites URLs that contain a plus character to a properly URL-encoded version. This ensures that clients access objects in S3 in a consistent way, and avoids any issues with Amazon S3's special handling of the plus character.

See https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/4891 for more details.

commits.body:
Rewrite URLs with plus characters on CloudFront

The CloudFront distribution for crates.io has been updated to rewrite
URLs that contain a plus character to properly URL-encode the path. This
ensures that clients access objects in S3 in a consistent way, and
avoids any issues with Amazon S3's special handling of the plus
character.

Use CloudFront functions for crates.io

Instead of using AWS Lambda functions to rewrite URLs, we are using
CloudFront functions which are simpler and cheaper.

pull_request.title: Enable cross-region replication on production Asset Manager S3 bucket
pull_request.body:
The changes in this PR enable cross-region replication on the main S3 bucket currently used by the Asset Manager app.

The motivation behind this is to (eventually) replace the nightly cron job which uses Duplicity to backup the Asset Manager files from NFS to one of the off-site backup S3 buckets. This will be a step towards being able to decommission NFS, or at least the Asset Manager bit of it.

Note that he changes in this PR are intended to be applied *after* the changes in [the preparatory PR][2]. The changes in this PR are all in the final commit with subject line: "Enable replication on Asset Manager S3 bucket in production". I plan to rebase this branch against master after the preparatory PR has been merged. I had to split the changes into two PRs, because there was an ordering problem with switching on versioning on the main bucket and enabling replication.

Note also that these changes are closely based on the [S3 cross-region replication example in the Terraform documentation][1].

See alphagov/asset-manager#146 for more details.

[1]: https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/aws/r/s3_bucket.html#using-replication-configuration
[2]: https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-terraform-provisioning/pull/140

I tested the changes in this PR in a non-GDS AWS account as follows:

1. Created an AWS IAM user, `jm-govuk-terraform-provisioning` in Admin group, i.e. with AdministratorAccess policy.
2. Created an AWS S3 bucket with name `jm-govuk-terraform-state-integration` to store Terraform state for the integration environment.
3. Created an AWS S3 bucket with name `jm-govuk-terraform-state-production` to store Terraform state for production environment.
4. Exported the following environment variables:

```
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=<redacted>
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=<redacted>

TERRAFORM_STATE_S3_BUCKET_REGION=eu-west-2
TERRAFORM_STATE_S3_BUCKET_NAME_PREFIX=jm-govuk-terraform-state

TF_VAR_account_id=jm-govuk-terraform-provisioning
TF_VAR_bucket_name=jm-govuk-assets
```

commits.body:
Add production-specific Asset Manager S3 bucket config

I'm planning to change the config of just the production S3 bucket in
order to enable cross-region replication for just that bucket. By making
this change first it should be easier to see what's going on.

Extract Asset Manager policy & its document into its own file

I'm about to add more policies to this project related to cross-region
replication and I think breaking the files up a bit will make it easier
to see what's changed.

Add Asset Manager backup S3 bucket in production

I want to setup cross-region replication for the Asset Manager S3
bucket. This new S3 bucket is intended to be used as the target for the
replication and this is why it has its region set to `eu-west-2` i.e. so
that it's different from the default region which is `eu-west-1` as
defined in `configs/common_variables.tf`.

Note also that I had to introduce a new AWS provider in order to use the
appropriate AWS API endpoint to create the backup S3 bucket.

Enable versioning on Asset Manager S3 buckets in production

I want to setup cross-region replication from the main S3 bucket to the
backup bucket. Setting up this replication requires that both source and
target buckets have versioning enabled.

Add IAM policy for Asset Manager backup

This policy sets up the relevant permissions on the source and target S3
buckets. Note that the actual replication hasn't been setup at this
point.

Add IAM role for Asset Manager backup

And associate it with the relevant policy using a policy attachment.
Note that the actual replication hasn't been setup at this point.

Enable replication on Asset Manager S3 bucket in production

This sets up cross-region replication in production from the main
Asset Manager S3 bucket to the backup bucket.

This is to (eventually) replace the nightly cron job which uses
Duplicity to backup the Asset Manager files from NFS to one of the
off-site backup S3 buckets.

pull_request.title: Enable lifecycles in buckets
pull_request.body:
We should enable and deploy lifecycles in S3 buckets that we use for backups so that we don't keep backups forever and waste lots of money. 

This adds the feature. Further details in commits. 

/cc @rjw1 for lifecycle lengths in https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-terraform-provisioning/commit/ac105ab0a5ae38fbf69167e072f8970a4a61c3e8

commits.body:
Add lifecycle to private_s3_bucket module

This means that a default setting can be enabled for this default
bucket used across backups.
Enable default lifecycle on backup buckets

Enable lifecycles on MongoDB backup buckets

We have two different buckets:

 - The bucket which contains full backups taken every 15 minutes expires
   after 7 days
 - The bucket which contains daily backups moves objects into cheaper
   storage after 30 then 60 days, and then expires after 90 days

pull_request.title: sets up S3 bucket for transition logs
pull_request.body:
We want the lowest-cost storage class for these logs as they will
seldomly be accessed, such as in a DR scenario. Unfortunately
terraform does not currently support lifecycle configuration, so
we will need to manage this aspect manually.

pull_request.title: Add a VPC endpoint for S3
pull_request.body:
The lack of any VPC endpoints is a non-trivial cost – about $400 a month in managed NAT Gateway, and that was before anybody started using Archivematica for serious work.

This change adds an S3 VPC endpoint to the workflow and workflow-stage VPC, which should dramatically cut those costs.

I haven't set up other endpoints yet because I'm not sure what other services we're using; I'm guessing S3 is probably the bulk of the load.

For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4325

### What is this PR trying to achieve?

Reduce the cost of running Goobi and Archivematica.

### Who is this change for?

For people who like money.

pull_request.title: Upgrade the root volume type to gp3
pull_request.body:
## 🗣 Description ##

This pull request:
- Upgrades the root volume type to gp3
- Removes the `delete_on_termination` line

## 💭 Motivation and context ##

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are intertwined with gp2.

Since `delete_on_termination = true` is the default, so there is no need to specify it.

## 🧪 Testing ##

See cisagov/cool-assessment-terraform#148 for an example of how I tested identical changes in another repository.

## ✅ Checklist ##

- [x] This PR has an informative and human-readable title.
- [x] Changes are limited to a single goal - _eschew scope creep!_
- [x] All relevant type-of-change labels have been added.
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](../blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] These code changes follow [cisagov code standards](https://github.com/cisagov/development-guide).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass.

commits.body:
Upgrade the root volume type to gp3

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better
performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the
volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are
intertwined with gp2.

Also remove the delete_on_termination line, since
delete_on_termination = true is the default, so there is no need to
specify it.

pull_request.title: Include name of bucket as label for cost analysis
pull_request.body:
If we create numerous buckets with a single instance of this module they will all have the same labels as it stands today.

When exporting cost metrics to bigquery we may want to distinguish the cost per bucket.

When performing cost queries, labels are the way to group resources today (unfortunately we cannot query on bucket name), adding the unique name as a label is a good way to perform a query on a single bucket with regards to its' cost. Until Big Query cost analysis let's us query on the bucket name, this is a workaround.

Thoughts?

commits.body: Include name of bucket as label for cost analysis

pull_request.title: Await Athena Query Completion
pull_request.body:
Bucket notifications are used to continue app flow after Athena Query
results arrive. The reason for designing the application like this is to
limit Lambda Function runtime. This is done by invoking each function asynchronously.

1. The user submits the google form.
2. The API Gateway receives the post and triggers the collection Lambda
Function.
3. The collection Lambda Function stores the post data and triggers the
setup_processing Lambda Function.
4. The setup_processing Lambda Function starts execution of an Athena Query.
5. The Athena Query results file creation invokes the processing Lambda Function (via bucket notification).
6. The processing Lambda Function starts execution of an Athena Query.
7. The Athena Query results file creation invokes the response Lambda Function (via bucket notification).
8. The response Lambda Function formats the data into an email, sends
it, and invokes the cleanup Lambda Function.
9. The cleanup Lambda Function runs to remove temp files.
10. The user receives the Shooting Insights email.

- Athena query completion times can vary greatly and bucket
notifications are used to trigger lambda functions that require the
query results
- New Lambda function setup_processing ensures that the Athena table is
created before any queries are run against it
- Add a processing s3 bucket
- Add a temp bucket
  - This bucket is used for sharing data between the lambda functions (primarilly the new event data
  and athena invocation IDs)
- Add bucket lifecycles to expire old data, incomplete uploads, and to
transition data to cheaper storage tiers
  - The intelligent archiving option is being used
  - It may be better to explicitly specify a storage type transition
  after x number of days instead of using intelligent archiving
- Bucket notifications
  1. Processing
    - Notification attached to processing s3 bucket
    - Invokes processing lambda
    - Awaits create table athena query completion
  2. Response
    - Notification attached to athena s3 bucket
    - Invokes response lambda
    - Awaits select query completion

commits.body:
Await Athena Query Completion

Bucket notifications are used to continue app flow after Athena Query
results arrive. The reason for designing the application like this is to
limit Lambda Function runtime. This is done by invoking each function asynchronously.

1. The user submits the google form.
2. The API Gateway receives the post and triggers the collection Lambda
Function.
3. The collection Lambda Function stores the post data and triggers the
setup_processing Lambda Function.
4. The setup_processing Lambda Function starts execution of an Athena Query.
5. The Athena Query results file creation invokes the processing Lambda Function (via bucket notification).
6. The processing Lambda Function starts execution of an Athena Query.
7. The Athena Query results file creation invokes the response Lambda Function (via bucket notification).
8. The response Lambda Function formats the data into an email, sends
it, and invokes the cleanup Lambda Function.
9. The cleanup Lambda Function runs to remove temp files.
10. The user receives the Shooting Insights email.

- Athena query completion times can vary greatly and bucket
notifications are used to trigger lambda functions that require the
query results
- New Lambda function setup_processing ensures that the Athena table is
created before any queries are run against it
- Add a processing s3 bucket
- Add a temp bucket
  - This bucket is used for sharing data between the lambda functions (primarilly the new event data
  and athena invocation IDs)
- Add bucket lifecycles to expire old data, incomplete uploads, and to
transition data to cheaper storage tiers
  - The intelligent archiving option is being used
  - It may be better to explicitly specify a storage type transition
  after x number of days instead of using intelligent archiving
- Bucket notifications
  1. Processing
    - Notification attached to processing s3 bucket
    - Invokes processing lambda
    - Awaits create table athena query completion
  2. Response
    - Notification attached to athena s3 bucket
    - Invokes response lambda
    - Awaits select query completion

pull_request.title: Better tagging
pull_request.body:
This improves our tagging so that:

- we can get better information in Cost Explorer by using the approved cost tags (Name, Environment, Service, Source etc)
- more things have Name tags so we know what they are
- things are clearly tagged `Service: observe-prometheus` or `Service: alertmanager` so we know which bits do what
- tags are used more consistently
- we get rid of tags like `product` that always had the same value (like `paas`).

commits.body:
[infra-security-groups] better tagging

"Environment" is more meaningful than "Stack name" and it's also one
of our billing tags.

[infra-networking] better tagging

"Environment" is more meaningful than "Stack name" and it's also one
of our billing tags.

Also "observe-production" is a better VPC name than "production-vpc".

[app-ecs-albs] better tagging

"Environment" is more meaningful than "Stack name" and it's also one
of our billing tags.

[app-ecs-services] delete unused bucket

That TODO looked interesting.  Some guy said in
b3a3bbd2b33b8ce003ac6c6f050b9c531d26335d that it would be okay to
delete.

The bucket is completely empty, I don't think we need it at all now.

[app-ecs-services] better tagging

"Environment" is more meaningful than "Stack name" and it's also one
of our billing tags.

I also tagged more resources than we used to tag:

 - the ECS cluster itself
 - the IAM User for SMTP
 - the IAM Role for the alertmanager task execution
 - task definitions

I chose not to tag ECS services, because they require opting in to the
new ECS ARN format and I'm not sure if/how to do that right now.

[prom-ec2/prometheus] better tagging

"Environment" is more meaningful than "Stack name" and it's also one
of our billing tags.

Also make sure everything is tagged with Service:
"observe-prometheus".

Also also tag lots more resources, including IAM Users and Roles.

pull_request.title: Remove multi nat-gateways in dev to save on cost
pull_request.body:
The dev enviroment currently creates three of every network component  based
on the configuration in the vpc module. I have added a small change which will
prevent the dev enviroment from creating a nat gateway for each AZ. If the
instance count is 3 in dev the single nat gateway will still be enabled. This
is fine since the dev enviroment is not HA enviroment. There will be extra routes
created to route traffic through the AZ which has all the active nat-gateway.

The current production enviroment currently supports an gateway per AZ. This is for HA
purposes.

Ticket: https://trello.com/c/UWSPjbFJ/532-add-singular-nat-gateways-to-aws-dev-environments

commits.body:
Remove multi nat-gateways in dev to save on cost

The dev enviroment currently creates three of every network component  based
on the configuration in the vpc module. I have added a small change which will
prevent the dev enviroment from creating a nat gateway for each AZ. If the
instance count is 3 in dev the single nat gateway will still be enabled. This
is fine since the dev enviroment is not HA enviroment. There will be extra routes
created to route traffic through the AZ which has all the active nat-gateway.

The current production enviroment currently supports an gateway per AZ. This is for HA
purposes.

pull_request.title: Reduce size of dev EC2 instances
pull_request.body:
## What

Aim of this PR is to reduce the size of the instances as in dev environments it's not necessary to run instances of `m4.xlarge`.

Updated setup.sh to remove the tfvars file when doing a clean of the stack, this is to ensure that when creating new dev stacks it uses the latest variables, previously devs were able to continue using the tfvars without any new vars being added resulting in default values for vars being used. 

In this case rather than using m4.xlarge use t2.small, and to pick up lower prometheus cpu and memoryReservation values for dev stacks.

The default dev stack `tfvars`, which is created by function `create_stack_configs` in the shell script, has been updated with default dev values which can be overridden by devs.

The prometheus task definition was changed in order to use the variables from tfvars for your stack if they exist otherwise default values will be used which are the default values for production and staging.

## Reference 

https://trello.com/c/Gn0fdyOr/447-destroy-our-dev-stacks-overnight-to-reduce-costs
comments: Nice, this will save some tax payer money :)
Nice work :)

commits.body:
Update setup.sh and prometheus task definition

Updated setup.sh to remove the tfvars file when doing a clean of the stack, this is to ensure that when creating new dev stacks it uses the latest variables. In this case rather than using m4.xlarge use t2.small, and to pick up lower prometheus cpu and memoryReservation values for dev stacks.

The default stack tfvars has been updated with default dev values which can be overridden by devs.

The prometheus task definition was changed in order to use the variables from tfvars for your stack if they exist otherwise default values will be used which are the values for production and staging.

pull_request.title: Add an ASG schedule for dev stacks
pull_request.body:
## What

The schedule is based on UTC times, so during BST the schedule will start at 19:00 rather than 18:00, but this is probably ok for the moment.

The default list of cron schedules is based around the core hours of 9 - 18 hours, Monday to Friday.

As developers can spin up the instances outside of these core hours to ensure that the EC2 instances are terminated the scheduled EC2 termination will be scheduled for at each hour outside of the core hours.

If you have a different working pattern, you can add the `asg_dev_scaledown_schedules` variable in your tfvars files with a list of cron schedules.

## Reference

https://trello.com/c/Gn0fdyOr/447-destroy-our-dev-stacks-overnight-to-reduce-costs
comments:
Spins up fine for me. Nice work

Left three very minor comments which you can take or leave.

Overall, trying to spin down every hour during out of hours might be overkill as opposed to just once at the beginning of out of hours but if it ever causes a problem we can iterate this solution.

commits.body:
Add an ASG schedule for dev stacks

The schedule is based on UTC times.
The default list of cron schedules is based around the core hours of 9 - 18 hours, Monday to Friday.
As developers can spin up the instances outside of these core hours to ensure that the EC2 instances are terminated the scheduled EC2 termination will be scheduled for at each hour outside of the core hours.
If you have a different working pattern, you can add the `asg_dev_scaledown_schedules` variable in your tfvars files with a list of cron schedules.

pull_request.title: Add Terraform configuration for ECS cluster
pull_request.body:
Resolves #1 

Mostly based on these two examples: [Setting up ECS with Terraform](https://blog.ulysse.io/post/setting-up-ecs-with-terraform/) and [Complete ECS](https://github.com/terraform-aws-modules/terraform-aws-ecs/tree/master/examples/complete-ecs).

The `module` blocks are 3rd party Terraform modules that define the configuration for more complicated stuff like Virtual Private Clouds (VPC) and Auto Scaling Groups that require a bunch of configuration, so using the modules simplifies things.

In terms of ECS, this configuration sets up an ECS cluster with no services and EC2 instances that will join the cluster on startup. The VPC is needed as a place for the EC2 instances to live, and the Auto Scaling Group is needed so that the number of EC2 instances can grow or shrink automatically based on a given metric (like CPU usage).

commits.body:
Add ECS cluster and instance profile config

Just creates an ECS cluster and IAM instance role and policy
attachments.

Also added a "name" variable to differentiate deployments.

Add Terraform config for VPC and autoscaling group

The VPC has a NAT that allows the EC2 instances in the private subnets
to be able to connect to the ECS cluster. I think the NAT gateway will
cost some small amount of money per hour.

The autoscaling group spawns the EC2 instance(s) that will connect to
the ECS cluster and will eventually run the actual services/tasks.

pull_request.title: gce: local redis in gcp to reduce network latency
pull_request.body:
As part of the investigation into https://github.com/travis-ci/worker/pull/564 we discovered what looks like a lot of time being spent on network latency when talking to redis.

Redis is in AWS `us-east-1`, whereas the workers are in GCP `us-central1`. The goal here is to make the redis instance local to the workers to make that network negligible.

This patch introduces a local redis instance per project. They cost about 50 bucks each, which is comparable to the 120 we are paying for the heroku-based one currently.

There are still some open questions about failovers, but those questions exist with our current setup too. :)

refs https://github.com/travis-ci/reliability/issues/222

commits.body: gce-staging-1: local redis in gcp to reduce network latency
terrafmt (carmen owes me a dollar)

pull_request.title: macstadium: separate worker pool for free jobs on com staging
pull_request.body:
As part of the merge, we are wanting to have a separate worker pool for free jobs running on travis-ci.com. This is so that if there is a backlog, paying customers will be isolated. The plan is then to gradually adjust the pool sizes, essentially shifting capacity from `org` to `com-staging`, as we migrate more users over to com.

This is a first step, which creates a new `com-free` worker pool, which consumes from the `builds.macstadium6-free` queue in RabbitMQ. It is otherwise identical to the `com` pool.

refs https://github.com/travis-ci/reliability/issues/118

commits.body: macstadium: separate worker pool for free jobs on com staging

pull_request.title: clean up leaked vms from packer-build via gcloud-cleanup
pull_request.body:
## What is the problem that this PR is trying to fix?

We've been seeing leaked VMs with names such as `packer-5b153bb9-ceed-78bd-a83e-d37168b19bab`. Those VMs are launched by [packer-build](https://github.com/travis-infrastructure/packer-build).

This can happen in the case of a travis build being canceled.

Those leaked VMs cost us a couple hundred bucks per month. This tweak should make sure they get cleaned up.

Side-note: I also removed the `gce_project` module as it is unused. That code now lives in the `gce_worker_group` module.

## What approach did you choose and why?

`gcloud-cleanup` is our automation for deleting leaked job vms. It runs continuously. We can use it to clean up these packer VMs also, using the same threshold as job VMs (3 hours).

## How can you test this?

I manually set `GCLOUD_CLEANUP_INSTANCE_FILTERS` on `gcloud-cleanup-production-1` and it produced this log line:

```
time="2018-06-06T17:05:37Z" level=info msg=deleted component="instance_cleaner" instance=packer-5b153bb9-ceed-78bd-a83e-d37168b19bab reason=stale  
```

I manually verified that the leaked packer instances were removed.

## What feedback would you like, if any?

commits.body: clean up leaked vms from packer-build via gcloud-cleanup
remove unused gce_project module

We've hit bottlenecks in the SAN, which can't handle too many running

worker pool sizes, we prevent this and keep efficient job throughput.

pull_request.title: Docker registry pull-through cache for aws-staging-1
pull_request.body:
The intent here is to smooth out and generally improve the reliability of docker image pulling in AWS, as without such a layer our availability is directly affected by the Docker Hub API uptime and performance.  Added bonus: we're better Docker Hub citizens with this.

#### cool tricks

``` bash
aws s3 ls --recursive travis-shared-1-registry-images
```

#### net base cost changes

``` diff
--- a/monthly-costs
+++ b/monthly-costs
@@ @@
- $1243.92 - 2 * c3.4xlarge, 2 * t2.small
+   $59.70 - 2 * t2.small, 2 * t2.nano, 2 * t2.micro
```

~$1184.22/mo. savings

pull_request.title: increase worker memory
pull_request.body:
We have been experiencing timeouts and dropped connections between the master and client DBs.

Did some research into better configuration and increasing work memory may help the larger queries that have been failing. Running out of working memory could do that. The memory on the machines overall looks pretty good, so we think the problem is more granular.

research doc here https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zB3CZPaS0gY9vPaIhM5Xn3U-lIMOvsVaip77sIXpJmU/edit# 

The other thing we might want to try is rolling back max_standby_streaming_delay to 20 minutes, instead of an hour (It was originally set to 30s and that caused cancelation errors). That was not the cause of the issue, but it does seem that the error rate went up after that. 

@vrajmohan @ccostino what do you think?

commits.body:
We have been experiencing timeouts and dropped connections between the master and client DBs.
Did some research into better configuration and increasing work memory may help the larger queries that have been failing.
Running out of working memory could do that. The memory on the machines overall looks pretty good, so we think the problem is more granular.

It seems that the extra delay negatively affected performance but with a different set of errors,
We are rolling the standby streaming delay to try and find a happy medium
Define work_mem in kb and note the units. Look at the console for the units terraform expects.

pull_request.title: Remove alarms that require no action
pull_request.body:
We have a scraper which is triggering these alarms with 100's of requests every hour. We don't need to do anything when they're triggered so they're causing us unnecessary alarm fatigue and could result in us missing real problems. 

Increasing the trigger thresholds to over what the scraper causes will effectively cause the alarms to never trigger, which won't be any more use than simply deleting them. 

https://trello.com/c/sZqatZVp/4-2-reduce-alerts-that-require-no-action

commits.body:
Remove alarms for requests taking 5-10s

This alarm is triggered every hour by a scraper, and intermittently at
other times by scripts that call expensive API operations. We don't do
anything when the alert goes off and it's causing alert fatigue so turn
it off.

Remove router 429 alarm

We have a scraper which is triggering this alarm with 100's of requests
every hour. We don't need to do anything when the alarm is triggered,
so it's causing unnecessary alarm fatigue.

pull_request.title: Raise log streaming lambda function timeout to 10s
pull_request.body:
We've seen some occasional (a few per day) timeouts on the log
streaming lambda functions likely caused by slow Elasticsearch
responses.

Raising the timeout value from 5s to 10s might help reduce the number
of failed runs. We don't want a very high timeout value since if
Elasticsearch at any point starts to respond to requests very slowly
our functions will spend more time waiting which can very quickly
raise the AWS Lambda costs.

commits.body:
Raise log streaming lambda function timeout to 10s

We've seen some occasional (a few per day) timeouts on the log
streaming lambda functions likely caused by slow Elasticsearch
responses.

Raising the timeout value from 5s to 10s might help reduce the number
of failed runs. We don't want a very high timeout value since if
Elasticsearch at any point starts to respond to requests very slowly
our functions will spend more time waiting which can very quickly
raise the AWS Lambda costs.

pull_request.title: Add a more flexible aws-vpc module
pull_request.body:
Things I'm trying to address in this PR:
- Current module doesn't support subnets other than `/16` without rewriting the module
- Environments should have separate VPCs (especially production and staging) so one cannot inadvertently affect the other
- Less configuration needed to use the module
- Still supporting the existing automation in pentagon

This module addresses the concerns above while keeping the output parameters used by the current pentagon automation for generating kops configs. It will create as many subnets as it needs with the CIDR input given and return the same set of subnets as the original module but with different sizes.

I would like to suggest we move to this when generating new inventories.

Things I am not addressing:
- A migration plan for people using the existing module

commits.body:
Adjustments for new module ideas

Added a new module for creating vpcs for a single cluster at a time.

Added refactor supporting multiple AZs

This supports 2, 3 & 4 AZs by using another module inside the "single-cluster" module.

This method does not allow for scaling a cluster AZ footprint but would support different
types of VPC architectures for accommodating subnet sizes and efficient usage of IPv4
space.

pull_request.title: Allow "site" module to specify alias domains
pull_request.body:
There is a bit of assumption baked into this module about the fact that
the site is accessible at a URL in the format of
beta.aws.openoakland.org (i.e. a Route53 zone). By adding an "aliases"
option, we can tell Cloudfront that our site should also be accessible
via other domains, namely our preferred "openoakland.org".

The caveat here is that for the TLS certificate, Amazon makes us
validate all aliases. We can automatically validate the primary fqdn
since it's in Route53, but not any aliases. So, when running the
terraform for the first time, the user will have to manually create the
other domains (in Namecheap or wherever else) during the validation
step.

commits.body:
Allow "site" module to specify alias domains

There is a bit of assumption baked into this module about the fact that
the site is accessible at a URL in the format of
beta.aws.openoakland.org (i.e. a Route53 zone). By adding an "aliases"
option, we can tell Cloudfront that our site should also be accessible
via other domains, namely our preferred "openoakland.org".

The caveat here is that for the TLS certificate, Amazon makes us
validate all aliases. We can automatically validate the primary fqdn
since it's in Route53, but not any aliases. So, when running the
terraform for the first time, the user will have to manually create the
other domains (in Namecheap or wherever else) during the validation
step.

pull_request.title: Add s3 bucket to store Mercurial backups
pull_request.body:
We have several gigabytes of old repos sitting on an NFS volume
in SCL3. It's cheaper to store them in S3. Plus, we'll soon be
migrating a bunch of data and it is easier if we have less data to
migrate.

commits.body:
Fix S3 IAM policies for hg bundles buckets

s3:ListBucket can only apply to a bucket resource, not objects.

We move the grant of this permission to its own statement to clarify
this.

After this change, `terraform apply` works again.

Define an ACL policy for S3 buckets

An empty policy string appears to preserve whatever changes are made
in the AWS web console.

When deploying the hg bundles bucket in us-east-2, I uncovered that
existing buckets appeared to have manual ACL modifications made
in the AWS web console.

We have since updated the IAM policies for the buckets to confer
the appropriate permissiosn to provide read-only access to all
users.

In this commit, we set the ACL policy of the bucket to "private."
This isn't technically the "correct" ACL since the bucket is public.
But "private" is the default ACL and all permissions should be
granted via IAM policy, not ACL, as ACLs are kinda deprecated. So
"private" (no access by default) feels like the proper policy.

Add s3 bucket to store Mercurial backups

We have several gigabytes of old repos sitting on an NFS volume
in SCL3. It's cheaper to store them in S3. Plus, we'll soon be
migrating a bunch of data and it is easier if we have less data to
migrate.

pull_request.title: hgmo: s3 bucket for holding events (bug 1316952)
pull_request.body:
We want hg.mo to write a stream of log events to S3 for data
retention and for reference by other services. Some events are on
the larger side and exceed size limits in SNS and Kinesis Firehose.
So, we'll write all events to S3 and then reference the object URL
in SNS/Kinesis/etc events if the event is too large to fit in a payload.

This commit introduces an S3 bucket and policy to hold hg.mo
events. The hgnotifier user can write to the bucket. Anybody can
read from the bucket (because all data is public and already posted
to Pulse).

commits.body:
hgmo: s3 bucket for holding events (bug 1316952)

We want hg.mo to write a stream of log events to S3 for data
retention and for reference by other services. Some events are on
the larger side and exceed size limits in SNS and Kinesis Firehose.
So, we'll write all events to S3 and then reference the object URL
in SNS/Kinesis/etc events if the event is too large to fit in a payload.

This commit introduces an S3 bucket and policy to hold hg.mo
events. The hgnotifier user can write to the bucket. Anybody can
read from the bucket (because all data is public and already posted
to Pulse).

pull_request.title: UML-2478 - Allow lambda to assume cross account role when collecting cost data
pull_request.body:
# Purpose

Collect cost data for all opg accounts.

Fixes UML-2478

## Approach

Assume Role
- Add class for creating a cross account boto3 client
- Add assume role permissions to lambda execution policy
- Pass env var for cros account cost explorer role

Collecting Costs
- add filter to pull cost data for OPG accounts only
- Increase lambda timeout

Other
- Fix sarif uploading
- Add codeowners
- Use the latest v3 of the lambda python image
- Fix the lambda IAM role name for easier referencing across accounts
- Set container version during local terraform dev
- remove duplicate logging configuration

## Learning

- https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/lambda-function-assume-iam-role/
- https://boto3.amazonaws.com/v1/documentation/api/1.20.4/reference/services/ce.html#CostExplorer.Client.get_cost_and_usage
- https://boto3.amazonaws.com/v1/documentation/api/latest/reference/services/sts.html#STS.Client.close
- https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/with-statement-in-python/

Signed-off-by: Sameer Vohra <svohra@pivotal.io>
Adds missing `main.tf` terraform file

Starts moving towards new cluster w/ metrics segregation

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

Make use of non local disk; adds gcp-key make target

With the current version of the chart that we use, local ssds can't
really be used given that we can't make use of PVCs for local storage,
so, in this commit we go back to using a `pd-ssd` that is big enough for
our workloads.

This commit also includes a `gcp-key` make target that grabs the gcp key
from lpass.

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

hh: make use of local storage; adds provisionar bootstraping

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

tf: remove autoscaling; hh: bump garden net pool; metrics: upgd panels

- given that we can't autoscale with the local SSDs that we've been
using, removed that completely for now.

- updated the panels that relate to network metrics to use bits instead
of bytes in the data rate panels;

- increased the garden network pool and max number of containers to play
with the idea of running a bunch of containers per host to explore
what can happen there.

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

hh: move out of local ssds and preemptible machines; updates pools

This commit:
- removes the use of preemptible instances
  - jobs that had to run for a very long time and have multiple steps
  being run across different workers would make the whole build fail
  when a single worker goes away, making our use of preemptible
  instances hard.
- removes the use of local ssds
  - given that a pod that uses a pv provisioned by a local provisioner
  can only get scheduled again against that particular node (and in our
  use case, we expect to have VMs coming and going), that makes it a
  no-no.
- creates a `generic` pool for non-worker workloads (like metrics, web
  ...). This way we can not rely on the default pool that gke
  automatically creates for us.

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

Add bootstrapping section to README, re-bootstrap, remove internal db ip

- we were missing a bootstrapping section that detailed the process of
  getting the cluster from nothing to a fully formed one;
- `terraform/main.tf` was using the `-test` suffix in some resources
  like the CloudSQL and the k8s cluster, so I got rid of them all and
  re-bootstrapped the whole thing without those suffixes;
- using internal connections for CloudSQL end up being too complicated
  in terms of allowing the connections to happen using the beta
  "internal svcs connection" feature from GCP (see [1]).

[1]: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/123276199

iaas: add a `workers-2` to test out rootless

Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>

move to single worker node-pool

this commit changes our distribution of concourse workers in a way to
have more web nodes that are half the size (vertically) than before, as
we've never been really fully utilizing their resources anyway.

it moves us from having 2 worker node pools of vertically large
machines, to a single pool with more nodes that are half the size that
they previously were (16vcpu 32GBram 1TBdisk --> 8vcpu 16GBram
750GBdisk).

the reasoning for not performing a "divide by 2" on `disk` is that
that's a resource that's still very highly utilized mostly in terms of
IOPS, but eventually, in terms of space too.

to achieve that, the `cluster` terraform module was updated to use a map
of node pools (rather than a list) so that we can update the set of
pools without needing to manually perform terraform surgery.

terraform/deployments: add ci-pr workers

this commit is intended to allow the [`prs` pipeline] to co-exist with
`nci` in the `hush-house` gke cluster.

it does so by:

- adding a node pool to the cluster (`ci-workers-pr`) whose size is the
  same as we had previously in our BOSH deployment
- adding a deployment (`ci-pr`) that puts workers in such node pool.

As such deployment is supposed to run untrusted workloads, we needed a
way of restricting the network access that this deployment could have in
order to avoid lateral movements in the internal net (in the case of our
BOSH environment, we had a totally different network - in k8s, we'd need
to be in a separate cluster if we wanted to go w/ the same approach of
different nets).

This led us to enabling the enforcement of network policies in the
cluster, and creating a policy for `ci-pr` that would target the pods
delpoyed by it, effectively blocking internal connectivity to anything
we didn't want (i.e., anything that's not ci's TSA).

ps.: these changes have already been applied.

[`prs` pipeline]: https://nci.concourse-ci.org/teams/main/pipelines/prs

comments:
I started to regret this review after about 10 suggestions.

It looks like a lot but it's basically the same suggestion 24 times.
Looks ok to me @samcrang

commits.body: Upgrade Concourse modules to Terraform 0.12

Use more Terraform 0.12 idioms

Co-Authored-By: Philip Potter <philip.potter@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

Revert one of the idiomatic v0.12 Terraform changes

I don't particularly want to spend any time figuring out why this breaks but
without reverting this change we see errors like this using Terraform v0.12.20:

```
Error: Invalid index

  on .terraform/modules/concourse_pay_subnets/reliability-engineering/terraform/modules/concourse-subnets/routes.tf line 52, in resource "aws_route_table_association" "concourse_public":
  52:   route_table_id = aws_route_table.concourse_public[count.index].id
    |----------------
    | aws_route_table.concourse_public is object with 6 attributes
    | count.index is 1

The given key does not identify an element in this collection value.
```

What's curious is that this seems to work fine for the equivalent
`aws_route_table_association` for the private subnet.

pull_request.title: GPII-4476: Fix alert modification alert
pull_request.body:
This PR fixes alert modification issue on every run. Terraform doesn't handle this quite correctly, on that note the Monitoring API behaves differently to other GCP APIs where the payload would typically be present with a default value.

**Changes introduced:**
- Fix alert modification alert

**Downtime:**
None expected this is a zero-downtime change.

**Testing:**
Tested in dev environment.

commits.body: Fix alert modification alert

pull_request.title: [GPII-2862]: Add log-based metrics and alert policies to notify on critical security events
pull_request.body:
As it turned out after all my experiments with Forseti scanners – this is the most straightforward way to address the issue.
Since it is impossible to reliably distinguish between TF-managed and "rogue" instances, log-based metric and policy is configured to alert on all `compute.instances.insert` events. I don't think it is going to be a trouble for long-lived clusters (stg / prd), but it can potentially add some more alert noise for ephemeral clusters.
comments:
> I don't think it is going to be a trouble for long-lived clusters (stg / prd), but it can potentially add some more alert noise for ephemeral clusters.

I think this is going to alert on cluster node auto-upgrades and we already have a ticket to reduce alert noise, so it would be great not to introduce more.

After a quick look it seems a way to distinguish GKE node auto-upgrades might be by `protoPayload.authenticationInfo.principalEmail!="360407405272@cloudservices.gserviceaccount.com"` (example for prod, the number is project id).
Looks good so far.

Looks good in general. Thanks for switching to the audit logs 👍  and also for including the alert on enabled apis changes.

I have a concern about hardcoding API versions into the queries, some of the above methods are already available over different API versions and others might change in future. Perhaps writing the queries in a way that does not rely on a specific version might be more future-proof and also catch events that wouldn't be caught otherwise.

Example:

Instead of
```
"resource.type="gke_cluster"
"protoPayload.methodName="google.container.v1beta1.ClusterManager.CreateCluster"
```
do just partial match:
```
resource.type="gke_cluster"
protoPayload.methodName:"ClusterManager.CreateCluster"
```


Also as this seems to be becoming the solution to address unauthorized resources in our infra, what is the reasoning behind selecting only instance and cluster creation?

Looking at the APIs we have enabled, at least a couple seems to pop out that allow easy opportunities to be abused, like `cloudbuild.googleapis.com` or `dns.googleapis.com`.
Looks good 👍

pull_request.title: GPII-3707: Move keyring from global to infra_region
pull_request.body:
**Rendered docs: https://github.com/mrtyler/gpii-infra/blob/gpii-3707-regionalism/gcp/README.md**

Requires https://github.com/gpii-ops/exekube/pull/49, which can be safely merged on its own.
- [x] Merged and deployed

I'm finalizing documentation and the rollout plan but I think I'm done with the implementation, hence no WIP label.

### Changes
I tried to make targeted commits but there was a hard-to-remove detour where I thought I needed to change the Keyring name based on Region. Anyway, the main themes, ordered roughly by batches of commits:

1. Small cleanups, including removing Stepan's hack for GPII-3568. I think Stepan is removing that in one of his in-flight branches, but it was causing me trouble so I removed it here as well.
2. Refactor secrets.rb and its call sites in rake land. Use Keyrings in `infra_region` instead of `global`. Add some basic unit tests. I'm not a huge fan of classes but:
   * This is a classic use case for a class: data bundled with methods for working with that data
   * Dealing with environment variables in unit tests is kind of annoying (see vars_spec.rb).
   * I think instance variables (set via constructer parameters) are a more natural fit than environment variables, and they declutter the rake file a bit compared with passing things like `project_id` in every time.
3. Add some helpers to facilitate migration from the global keyring, and for moving between regions.

### Alternative approach
My main goal was to enable us to run GPII Cloud environments in any region. I have been able to do that in my tests, but the current approach has some downsides:
* It requires some extra `terraform import` steps because KMS Keyrings are indestructible and Keys have an unusual lifecycle
   * I think moving from region to region will be rare in practice
   * I've added some rudimentary automation for this, `rake import_keyring`
* Each environment has a single tfstate bucket in Multi-Region `US`, no matter in which Region the environment really runs

I have considered, but not yet tested, an alternative approach with a tfstate bucket in each region where we might wish to run an environment. This avoids the `terraform import` steps because tfstate in us-east1 can always point to the keyring in us-east1. I haven't pursued this avenue because:
* We need to migrate off of `global` Keyrings regardless, so something like this PR and its rollout plan will be necessary
* tfstate buckets are managed by common, so we'd need to create them ahead of time for each environment X region we want to have available
* Multiple tfstate buckets would allow (in fact, require) `apply_infra` resources (e.g. VPCs, public IPs) in each Region. This is a small waste and a small amount of extra clutter
* Multiple tfstate buckets would allow users to accidentally run two environments at once (e.g. one in us-east1, one in us-central1)
* DNS is still a singleton. The default behavior with multiple tfstate buckets would be "last one wins", which is not so bad but nonetheless adds a potential source of confusion.

### Exported logs
We have a decision to make about existing exported logs for stg and prd:
1. Delete them - how much value do they have?
1. Leave them alone - it is theoretically possible to decrypt and read the logs later as long as we are careful not to destroy the global Key used to write them
1. Re-encrypt them in place - this is the safest, but most expensive option
   * I think we can use a modified version of `rotate_tfstate_key` to accomplish this, but I haven't tested it yet.
- [x] Decided to keep prd logs

### Rollback plan
The basic idea is to undo the rollout by re-importing the `global` Keyring and Keys and re-encrypting data using the Old Keys. The steps here are for pointing the environment back to the Old Keyring. Other steps may be needed as well, depending on when the rollout was abandoned.

1. Revert this PR (i.e. go back to Old version of code)
   * The associated Exekube PR and resulting image may remain
1. Update gpii-infra to Old version
1. `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
1. `rake sh`
1. `unset GOOGLE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`
1. `cd /project/live/$ENV/secret-mgmt`
1. Replace the New Keyring and Keys with the Old Keyring and Keys:
```
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_key_ring.key_ring
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_key_ring.key_ring projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[0]
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[0] projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring/cryptoKeys/default
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[1]
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[1] projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring/cryptoKeys/gcp-stackdriver-export
```

### Rollout plan
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for dev-doe (skipping some steps since dev-doe is an ephemeral cluster), which will be deployed into a new region (us-east4) as a test case
- [x] Notify cloud-developers of required actions (see below)
- [x] Merge this PR, which will eventually run CI for dev-doe.
- [x] Verify everything looks correct. In particular, look out for changes to Keyrings and changes to the tfstate bucket as part of common-stg
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for stg
- [x] Promote common-prd
- [x] Verify everything looks correct in stg
   * plan-all in prd will fail, because migration steps haven't run there yet
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for prd
- [x] Re-run plan-all in prd. Verify everything looks correct
- [x] Promote prd
- [x] Re-encrypt prd's exported logs (see below)

#### Migration steps

"Old" refers to the tip of master / the latest deployed infrastructure from before this PR (i.e. with Keyrings and Keys in the "global" Region). "New" refers to code / infrastructure after this PR is merged.

1. Update to latest version of gpii-infra
1. `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
1. `rake update_exekube`
1. Replace the Old Keyring and Keys with the New Keyring and Keys:
   * `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake import_keyring`
   * EDIT: This didn't work in stg (and won't in prd) because there is no Keyring to import from us-central1. So we must create it.
      * Manually run `terragrunt state rm` commands to prevent globaly Kerying and Keys from being destroyed
      * Use the `terragrunt plan` steps below to verify that ONLY new Keyring and Keys are CREATED (no Old buckets or Keys destroyed)
      * Run `terragrunt apply`
1. Verify that `terragrunt plan` doesn't want to make any changes
   * `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake sh` and then inside shell:
   * `unset GOOGLE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`
   * `cd /project/live/$ENV/secret-mgmt`
   * `terragrunt plan`
   * Exit shell
1. `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake rotate_secrets_key`
1. `rake rotate_secrets_key"[gcp-stackdriver-export]"`
1. `rake` (perhaps via CI)
   * Should be mostly a no-op.
1. Fix encryption for exported logs bucket (see below)
1. Verify logs exported both before and after the migration are readable
   * [Go to bucket](https://console.cloud.google.com/storage/browser/gpii-gcp-prd-exported-logs?project=gpii-gcp-prd&authuser=1&organizationId=247149361674)
   * Navigate to some Old logs. Verify that you can view them (no KMS error)
   * Navigate to some New logs -- you may have to wait up to an hour for new logs to be exported. Verify that you can view them (no KMS error)
1. Disable (do *NOT* destroy!) Keys in `global` Keyring

#### Email to cloud-developers
```
Subject: New regions available for dev envs (action required)


Hi cloud developers,

Good news: It is now possible to create a dev environment in any Google Cloud region![1][2] Instructions are here:
https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/master/gcp/README.md#i-want-to-spin-up-my-dev-environment-in-a-different-region

Bad news: You must take action -- even if you are happy to stay in your current region -- to keep your cluster up-to-date. (Please do this migration separately, before trying out a new region. :))

If you are able to destroy your environment, the process is pretty standard:
* `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
* `rake destroy`
* Update gpii-infra to latest master
* `rake update_exekube`
* `rake destroy_hard`[3]
* `rake`

If you are not able to destroy your environment, you can safely migrate an existing environment. It's a little more complex, so you may want to consult Ops before pursuing this route:
* See "Rollout plan: Migration steps" in https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/329.

Please ping us in #ops if you have questions or any trouble!

Thanks,
the ops team


[1] I haven't tested anything outside of the US. Who will spin up the first GPII Cloud in Europe??

[2] Some infrastructure (the GCS Bucket where Terraform keeps its state) remains in the `US` multi-region.

[3] `destroy_hard` is a new helper command for destroying even more stuff related to your environment, like Terraform state and secrets.
```

#### Re-encrypt exported logs
1. After the migration step `rake rotate_secrets_key"[gcp-stackdriver-export]"`, New exported logs will be readable, but Old exported logs will not. This is because Terraform deletes the IAM binding that allows GS to access the Old Key when adding the IAM binding for the New Key.
1. Manually add a binding for the Old Key:
   * `rake sh`
   * Get the appropriate Serviceaccount user and Role from the New Key:
      * `gcloud kms keys get-iam-policy --location $TF_VAR_infra_region --keyring keyring gcp-stackdriver-export`
   * Use this info to add the same binding to the Old Key:
      * `gcloud kms keys add-iam-policy-binding gcp-stackdriver-export --location global --keyring $TF_VAR_keyring_name --member serviceAccount:service-111111111111@gs-project-accounts.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/cloudkms.cryptoKeyEncrypterDecrypter`
1. Rewrite everything in the exported logs bucket using the New Key:
   * `gsutil -m rewrite -r -k gs://${TF_VAR_project_id}-exported-logs`
1. Remove manually added binding

pull_request.title: [GPII-2782] - 1 - High-Level Task: Secure Backups
pull_request.body:
This is the first PR of the implementation of exporting backups task. This PR cover this 3 parts:

1. Backup exporter Service account and de permissions needed at the common level to allow cloudbuild to perform the operations. (The command `gcloud compute image export` creates a Cloudbuild job that makes all the work using a VM)
1. Backup exporter Helm Chart
1. Backup exporter GCP module.

This PR only affects to the common part as it will enable the APIs involved and create the backup-exporter service account. This PR can be promoted safely to prd.

If the common part is merge it will help me with the implementation of the rest of the task, because I wouldn't need to redeploy my cluster every time that the pipeline is executed.

This is the Terragrunt definition I'm using for testing, just in case someone wants to give a try:
```
# gcp/live/dev/k8s/kube-system/backup-exporter/terraform.tfvars 
# ↓ Module metadata

terragrunt = {
  terraform {
    source = "/project/modules//backup-exporter"
  }

  dependencies {
    paths = [
      "../k8s-snapshots",
    ]
  }

  include = {
    path = "${find_in_parent_folders()}"
  }
}

# ↓ Module configuration (empty means all default)

destination_bucket = "gs://gpii-backup-dev-alfredo"
replica_count      = 2
schedule           = "*/10 * * * *"
```
Tasks left for the next PRs:
- A way to create the destination bucket. A little bit tricky, because I need to give permissions (first part of the pipeline) to this bucket and I need the SA created first (which is created in later steps).
- Add the module in the Terragrunt definition of prd (is it needed in stg and dev clusters?)
- Document how to restore the cluster using the exported snapshots
- Alert when a backup fails
comments:
Thanks for sharing this early in the process. I have some high-level questions.

0. You may have said this once during standup but: have you successfully restored from a backup created using this strategy?

1. How often will the backup task run? How often does the Instance get created and destroyed?

2. How will we expire backups?

3. Why is ssh access needed? Maybe temporary for development/debugging?

4. Brendan's original specification calls for "cross-account, cross-region". That's sort of AWS specific, but I think the idea is to both improve resilience (cross-region in case one region goes down) and to make it harder for automation or human error to delete or modify the backups (cross-account so that "delete all the Snapshots" cannot delete both the primary Snapshots and the backups). Maybe storing the backups in a GCS bucket (or whatever) in a different Project is the appropriate metaphor for GCP?

What does the team think of this requirement?

Thanks Alfredo for this. I'll not go into details of this solution at this stage, but I'm a bit concerned about the overall approach. I'm thinking that spinning up a VM to do this, mounting disks etc.... might be unnecessary and opens a lot of questions, not only about security and data encryption.

What if we can do this VMless? And using `gcloud` native tools?

I would consider following:
- Export the disk images to GCS Bucket, this would involve:
  - `gcloud compute images create` which creates an image from a persistent disk or a snapshot
  -  `gcloud compute images export` which exports an image to GCS Bucket (see https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/images/export-image for details)
(if we want to use TF, I would check - it might have corresponding resources).

At this stage, we have backups in GCS and we can do pretty much anything we want with those. If this would stay within GCP, I would use `gsutil cp` that can copy data between buckets, even across different projects, without actually ever downloading them. `gsutil` seems to be even able to handle transfers from GCS to S3 (although in this case the data are pushed through the machine running the command).

I think all this can be run either on Kubernetes (maybe `CronJob`), or maybe even better as part of some CI build (perhaps CloudBuild?). In general, I would a) try to avoid pulling data to the client machine if possible (ie. do direct transfers between buckets) b) if not leverage fast connectivity inside the cloud (ie. don't run this on Gitlab if we have to pull data)

And I would try to avoid having to spin-up, manage and monitor new infrastructure, unless really necessary.

I believe this would allow us to simplify things a lot, leverage GCP data encryption and authz/n mechanisms, speed up and be less error-prone and easier to maintain.

> What does the team think of this requirement?

I would probably relax this to use GCS under different Project, and maybe Organization even. I would use perhaps multi-regional buckets, and Nearline/Coldline to reduce costs. And I would use GCS native Lifecycle Mgmt. to manage downgrade of the storage classes and deletion of objects (see. https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/lifecycle).

Cool Alfredo, I like this way more 👍 seems pretty neat.

Do you have any plans on monitring that the backups are happening?

> it's the number of couchdb replicas, which should be the same as the number of snapshots made at the same time.

Ok, looking at this again based on your previous answer I see one issue:

```
SNAPSHOTS=$(gcloud compute snapshots list --sort-by=~creationTimestamp,STATUS --limit={{ .Values.replicaCount }} --format="value[separator=';'](name,status)" | cut -f1 -d\;)
```

If the `replicaCount` is used to match number of replicas, we're not guaranteed to get consistent backup. Due to how snapshots happen, they don't happend atomically from all the instances at the same time. So imagine state of snapshots being smth like this (ordered by timestamp desc):

```
ReplicaA - 4pm snapshot
ReplicaB - 3pm snapshot
ReplicaA - 3pm snapshot
```

Above code with the `replicaCount` of two would backup snapshot from 4pm from replicaA and snapshot from 3pm from replicaB.

Or even worse, imagine:
```
ReplicaA - 4pm snapshot
ReplicaA - 3pm snapshot
ReplicaB - 3pm snapshot
```

The code would back up two snapshots from replica A, but not from replica B.

I'm not sure if the first example is an issue, but the second I think definitely is.

Maybe we can leverage predictable replicas/snapshot naming to always select the latest snapshot of each replica?

LGTM for the purposes of merging the permissions changes so you don't have to manually re-create them all the time.

I think it will be helpful to link/copy the outstanding items from this PR into the new PR, since you are picking up the work there.

pull_request.title: [GPII-3418]: Tune resource requests one more time
pull_request.body:
This is the long-term solution I promised.

For dev clusters I had to keep requests lowered in order to stay on cheaper `n1-standard-2` nodes.

For staging / prod clusters:
* To have "more predictable" scheduling with requests = limits
* To also have more replicas of preferences, flowmanager and couchdb (similarly to AWS setup)
* And finally, to have enough room for rolling updates with `maxUnavailable: 0`

I suggest to use `n1-highcpu-4` instances. They are a bit cheaper than `n1-standard-4` and have significantly less RAM (4GB vs 15GB), but since we are very far away from hitting RAM limit, it seems like the most optimal choice in our situation.

Changing node type will most likely cause Terraform to attempt to recreate the cluster. I am not sure if there is a way around this issue for staging and prod, I am open to suggestions!

Using container_node_pool should improve this situation:
https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3419

commits.body: Use n1-highcpu-4 nodes for staging and prod
Don't do env-based interpolations in modules
Update Terragrunt configurations with env-specific values

I realize this is an early draft, so if your response to any of these things is "yes, I know, I just haven't done that yet," feel free to reply "🔜" or similar :p.
