A slightly better answer, possible with this approach, is "Sorry, Alice, until Google culls some old Projects you'll have to re-use your last dev environment by specifying `TF_VAR_project_id` directly".

pull_request.title: GPII-3125 Init GCP organization
pull_request.body:
This code covers [GPII-3125](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3125), [GPII-3127](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3127), [GPII-3126](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3126) and [GPII-3128](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3128).

More info about how to apply this code is in the [README.md](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/35b4ba9f9657b0c25e23c0f0d488d386453c7dd6/common/README.md)

This pr includes the following changes:

- Move the rakefiles to a common part shared by all the project types
- Create the DNS structure for a complete organization, in AWS and GCP
- The organization details are parametrized.
- Make idempotent the creation of the initial resources used by each environment
- Move some rake tasks to the Docker container
- `rake sh` gives a shell inside the container without making changes.

This is the plan to merge this PR:

1. Merge the PR :)
1. Let the CI test all until `stg`. This should create the initial resources for test1.gpii.net and create/destroy a complete dev testing cluster.
1. Manually import in the `prd` state file the projects already created in the organization in order to avoid naming conflicts and/or increase the projects quota.
1. Import the DNS zones that match the [DNS pattern](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/d60a61a5ee8d03cd11fb205cfceedbba817f5945/shared/rakefiles/vars.rb#L28-L36), delete others.
1. Promote to `prd` to recreate all the initial resources, DNS zones left, ns registries, SA of each project, activate API services and update the TF state of the common part.
1. Each individual project should refresh the TF state simply running `rake`, the CI will do automatically.
1. Re-run the complete pipeline in order to check that the idempotency works as expected.
comments:
This looks pretty good, Alfredo! I still think the strategy is sound. Most of my feedback is naming and organization changes that I hope will help with readability.

I haven't tried to run this code yet. Perhaps we should sit down together and go through it, make sure it works on my machine, make sure things that require Organization admin are idempotent, etc.

Lookin' good. I suggested a couple more small things (mostly deleting code :)).

Thank you for using merge instead of rebase so that I can keep track of what I've already reviewed. I'm fine with Stepan's suggestion of using rebase to clean up the history before merging to master.

I think the rest of your plan looks good. I'm fine with punting the stuff you punted.

Thanks for helping to test this code, Stepan!

The bug fixes generally look good.

I like the parameterization and the ability to do testing!

It looks like this branch does not contain my latest changes for `@serviceaccount_key_file` management. You're probably already aware and have a plan for this :).
Reminder that there are a few comments from my last review (8 days ago) that remain unresolved.
Some minor changes.

This review contains some more significant changes.

In particular, I have questions about the CI strategy.

1. Spinning up and then destroying a GCP dev cluster twice -- once as part of `gcp-dev`, once as part of `common-stg` -- is expensive and slow. As currently implemented, `common-stg` must complete successfully before `aws-stg` and `gcp-stg` can run.

2. There's a strange cycle where:
* Developer changes the way `common-prd` deploys dev environments.
* Developer merges their changes, triggering a CI pipeline.
* `gcp-dev` runs, but `common-prd` changes haven't been deployed yet.
* Later, `common-prd` runs, deploying the developer's changes.
* In the *next* pipeline (perhaps as much as a day later), `gcp-dev` finally runs in a world where the developer's changes have been deployed.

Maybe the pipeline should have a different order?
* setup
* unit-test
* common-stg
* common-promote-to-prd [1]
* common-prd
* dev [2]
* promote-to-stg
* stg
* promote-to-prd
* prd

[1] It's awkward to have a manual step early in the pipeline. Are we confident promoting common to prd automatically if common-stg succeeds?

[2] The dev Stage, and all subsequent Stages, include `aws-` and `gcp-` Jobs.

I'd like to discuss before we merge this PR.

    ingressPolicies:

pull_request.title: Update indexes when index definitions change
pull_request.body:
The null_resource creating and cleaning up indexes was triggering when
the filename changed, but the filename in question was a temporary file
whose name wouldn't change with the content. This commit changes the
triggering to occur when the index content changes.

This pull request is based on #5. If needed it can be refactored to be an independent pull request, otherwise it should be merged after #5 is merged.

commits.body:
Update indexes when index definitions change

The null_resource creating and cleaning up indexes was triggering when
the filename changed, but the filename in question was a temporary file
whose name wouldn't change with the content. This commit changes the
triggering to occur when the index content changes.
Update gcloud commands to use preferred subcommand syntax

Extract inline provisioner scripts to external files

This commit extracts the inline calls to `gcloud` to external scripts,
and replaces the `gcloud `service account activation with a credentials
override that doesn't need setup. Extracting these scripts allows us to
run linters on the scripts, call and test them independently, and
reduces the cost of development on those scripts.

pull_request.title: Update the IAM roles for the new billing permissions
pull_request.body:
A while back AWS [changed their permissions model for some billing-related tasks][1], and they've been yelling us about them ever since. We used the deprecated IAM permissions in two places:

* the standard billing role in every account
* the CloudHealth role we create for D&T monitoring

These two deprecations have been fixed in the following ways:

* the standard billing role is gone; we haven't used it in the years it existed and it's unnecessary maintenance drag
* the CloudHealth role has been updated with the new policies from D&T

[1]: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws-cloud-financial-management/changes-to-aws-billing-cost-management-and-account-consoles-permissions/

commits.body: Remove the unused billing role
export the entire role, not just individual attributes

pull_request.title: Consolidate the CloudHealth role in the AWS module
pull_request.body:
Some cleanup for https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/5655; already applied.

The CloudHealth role should be created in every AWS account we manage; it's used by D&T to get read-only access into our accounts and monitor cost, usage, and so on. Previously we were creating it for every account separately; now it's created as part of our AWS account module.

The commit history includes the Terraform `moved` blocks I used to apply this change; in all accounts it was a no-op.

I also had to make some changes to the digitisation account in particular; when I ran `terraform plan`, it threatened to delete a bunch of resources. It looks like somebody started upgrading this to a newer version of the Terraform provider, applied their changes, but never committed. Fortunately, it was sufficient to copy the Terraform "this is what I'm about to delete" in, and it was a no-op apply, so I don't think it's a big deal.

commits.body: Add an extra comment about what CloudHealth is

Move the cloudhealth role into our AWS account module

We need to create this role for every AWS account we manage, so push it
into the module alongside our other standard roles (e.g. dev, read-only).

This patch includes the `moved` blocks I needed to get this to apply
cleanly, and some changes to the digitisation stack that were flagged by
Terraform -- it looks like somebody tried to fix these deprecations at
another time, applied their changes, but didn't commit them.

These plan/applies are all no-ops.
Fix a typo in a resource name
Remove all the `moved` blocks
Remove a couple of unused variables

Apply auto-formatting rules

pull_request.title: Add the missing roles to the costs report Lambda
pull_request.body:
We create roles in each account for the Lambda to assume, so it can fetch the costs associated with that account.  The permissions for the role need to be configured in two places:

1) In the other account ("Anyone in platform can assume role X")
2) In the platform account ("Lambda can assume role X")

But for these three accounts, only (1) was configured.  This patch adds (2).

pull_request.title: Double the number of Buildkite instances at peak; reduce disk usage
pull_request.body:
Last month we spent ~$75 on r5.large instances and ~$100 on gp2 volumes. Our BuildKite setup is also imbalanced:

* It's possible to max out our 30 workers. At peak build times, you can be waiting 20m+ for your build to start. Slow!
* 150GB is massive, a quick spin through our current worker pool suggests they have ~144GB or so free with a warm cache (this is logged as part of our pre-job hook). Wasteful!

This change tries to rebalance that spending: take some of the money we're spending on gp2 volumes, and spend it on running more workers instead. I don't expect it to impact the bill much, but it should avoid our builds getting throttled because too many people are building at once.

commits.body: Double the number of Buildkite instances at peak; reduce disk usage

pull_request.title: Tweak our BuildKite setup
pull_request.body:
This change is already applied.

Currently nothing is running in CI because the spot price of the r5.large instances we use has just passed $0.04:

> Launching a new EC2 instance. Status Reason: Your Spot request price of 0.04 is lower than the minimum required Spot request fulfillment price of 0.0411. Launching EC2 instance failed.

Since this is only a small part of our bill ($72/mo), we can safely increase the spot bid without breaking the bank.

We also spent $126 last month on gp2 EBS volumes, most of which will be our BuildKite runners. I'm reasonably confident that we don't actually need 250GB per instance, so I've reduced it and added a check that will help us spot if a job failed due to low disk space.

We spent ~$250/mo in NAT Gateway costs for CI; see [Cost Explorer](https://console.aws.amazon.com/cost-management/home?#/custom?excludeRIRecurringCharges=false&startDate=2021-02-20&excludeTax=false&excludeSupportCharges=false&endDate=2021-03-22&timeRangeOption=Custom&hasAmortized=false&excludeRIUpfrontFees=false&filter=%5B%7B%22dimension%22:%22Operation%22,%22values%22:%5B%22NatGateway%22%5D,%22include%22:true,%22children%22:null%7D%5D&isTemplate=true&groupBy=TagKeyValue:Name&forecastTimeRangeOption=None&excludeCredit=false&excludeTaggedResources=false&reportType=CostUsage&chartStyle=Line&granularity=Daily&excludeOtherSubscriptionCosts=false&hasBlended=false&excludeRefund=false&reportName=Daily%20API%20operation%20costs&excludeDiscounts=true&usageAs=usageQuantity&excludeCategorizedResources=false&excludeForecast=false)

A substantial part of this is likely to be sending Docker images to/from ECR – at $0.045/GB and ~200MB/application image, it stacks up. I'm hoping this bends the curve down a bit.

Tentatively closes https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4920

pull_request.title: Manage the logging cluster in Terraform; connect to it using a VPC endpoint
pull_request.body:
For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/5002

I didn't mean this to be quite so disruptive, but in for a penny, in for a pound.

This pull request adds a new Elasticsearch cluster for logging (`ec_deployment.logging`). It also adds traffic filters that allow it to receive traffic from every VPC into which we copy our shared logging secrets. These traffic filters are connected to VPC endpoints, which means logs can be sent cheaper than going over a managed NAT Gateway. It's a big diff, but a lot of it is repetition.

Next steps:

- [x] Get this cluster working with OIDC
- [x] Put this cluster behind logging.wellcomecollection.org
- [x] Set up index expiry for these logs, so we don't fill up the cluster's disk
comments: Phew! This is a big change - you've got it out neatly and v.quick too.

commits.body: Move the ES traffic filters + VPC endpoints to platform-infrastructure
Export the security group ID + traffic filters
Be more consistent about how these outputs are named
Try to get a logging cluster in Terraform
Put the PrivateLink secrets somewhere else
Put the new logging cluster behind logging.wellcomecollection.org

pull_request.title: Add some VPC endpoints for connecting to ECR
pull_request.body:
For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4920 and https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4926

We spend ~$300/mo on NAT Gateway in the CI VPC, when almost everything it does is talking within AWS. We should be able to make this cost less spiky.

Also add the Name tags to as many endpoints as can be done from this repo, both for ease of working in the console and cost allocation purposes.

pull_request.title: Break up the 'accounts' monolith configuration into per-account configurations
pull_request.body:
Spun out of https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4802

Currently the managed roles and IAM policies for every account sit in one Terraform configuration. This is a dangerous abstraction: I shouldn't run the risk of breaking something in *platform* if I want to change something in *storage*, and so on. It would be better if each account was managed in a separate configuration.

This PR illustrates what that might look like, by splitting out the digirati account into a new configuration. I haven't removed it from the main configuration yet, so we can drop this change non-destructively.

Before I start breaking things or doing more work, I'd like to get other opinions: **is this a good idea? Should I do it for the remaining accounts?**

Assuming it it, I'll finish this off, then move the VPC and CloudHealth definitions to live inside these configurations. Each configuration would contain the "base" state for each of our AWS accounts.

—

I've also written a Python script that works out what import statements to create based on the existing state in the `accounts` configuration

<details>
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python

import json
import shlex
import sys
from pprint import *

name = sys.argv[1]
role_arn = sys.argv[2]

tfstate = json.load(open('/Users/chana/Desktop/accounts.tfstate.json'))

for role_name in (
    "admin",
    "billing",
    "ci",
    "developer",
    "monitoring",
    "publisher",
    "read_only",
):
    terraform_id = shlex.quote(f"{name}-{role_name}")
    print(
        f"terraform import module.{name}_account.module.{role_name}_role.aws_iam_role.role {terraform_id}"
    )

for role_name, policy_id in [
    ('admin', 'admin'),
    ('billing', 'admin'),
    ('ci', 'ci_permissions'),
    ("developer", "developer_go_hog_wild"),
    ("developer", "developer_iam_user_group_deny"),
    ("developer", "developer_restrict_destructive_actions"),
    ('monitoring', 'billing'),
    ('monitoring', 'ecs'),
    ('publisher', 'ecr_power_user'),
    ('publisher', 'ssm_parameter_store_power_user'),
    ('read_only', 'test-attach'),
]:
    matching_resources = [
        r
        for r in tfstate['resources']
        if r.get('module') == f'module.{name}_account.module.{role_name}_role_policy' and r['type'] in {'aws_iam_role_policy', 'aws_iam_role_policy_attachment'} and r.get('name') == policy_id
    ]
    
    if len(matching_resources) == 1 and len(matching_resources[0]['instances']) == 1:
        resource_id = matching_resources[0]['instances'][0]['attributes']['id']
    else:    
        pprint(matching_resources)
        assert 0
    
    terraform_id = shlex.quote(resource_id)
    if role_name == 'read_only':        
        print(
            f"terraform import module.{name}_account.module.{role_name}_role_policy.aws_iam_role_policy_attachment.{policy_id} {name}-{role_name}/arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/ReadOnlyAccess"
        )
    else:
        print(
            f"terraform import module.{name}_account.module.{role_name}_role_policy.aws_iam_role_policy.{policy_id} {terraform_id}"
        )
```
</details>

pull_request.title: Delius DB EBS vol optimisation - delius-prod
pull_request.body:
Changes EBS volumes attached to DB instances in delius-prod:
- volume type from io1 to gp3 type
- set IOPS allocation to 4000
- set throughput to 1000

Ticket no. https://dsdmoj.atlassian.net/browse/NIT-241

commits.body: EBS vols cost optimisation in delius-prod

pull_request.title: Reduce DFI Instances size for identified cost savings

commits.body: Reducde DFI Instances size for identified cost savings

pull_request.title: ALS-3882 Increase LDAP instance types in production environments

commits.body: ALS-3882 Increase LDAP instance types in production environments

ALS-3882 Set LDAP instance type to m5.8xlarge
Even though m5.8xlarge ($1.776) has more memory, it costs less than the c5.9xlarge ($1.818) in the eu-west-2 region

pull_request.title: ALS-1712 Set ActiveMQ EFS throughput to 16MiB/s
pull_request.body: Following performance test results, and risk/cost evaluation here: [ALS-1712](https://jira.engineering-dev.probation.hmpps.dsd.io/browse/ALS-1712)

commits.body:
ALS-1712 Set ActiveMQ EFS throughput to 16MiB/s

Following performance test results, and risk/cost evaluation here: https://jira.engineering-dev.probation.hmpps.dsd.io/browse/ALS-1712

pull_request.title: ALS-2057 - Added configuration for LDAP EFS + reduced specs for root EBS volume
pull_request.body: Provisioned IOPS is no longer required for the root volume, as the LDAP data is now hosted on EFS. This should result in an EBS cost reduction.

commits.body:
Added configuration for LDAP EFS + reduced specs for root EBS volume

Provisioned IOPS is no longer required for the root volume, as the LDAP data is now hosted on EFS. This should result in an EBS cost reduction.

pull_request.title: Shuffle parameters for autoscaled nodes
pull_request.body:
These couple changes should help get the job queue under control now
that we're using a lot more node-level parallelism. EBS costs are also up since every node is getting 250 GB which is more than it needs (spot checked a bunch of nodes, never saw more than 65 GB in use). Queue got pretty backed up yesterday

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9407960/170364243-17e8335b-19b9-4d7a-9bf7-24149201f5a7.png)

commits.body:
Bump CPU-SMALL capacity to 200, reduce idle minutes to 1m

These couple changes should help get the job queue under control now
that we're using a lot more node-level parallelism.

pull_request.title: Add ARM-SMALL instance type
pull_request.body:
Same as in #24 this adds `r6g.large` instances under the
`ARM-SMALL` label so we can start testing and using those in CI (5x
cheaper than `m6g.4xlarge`). If that works well we can convert some
usages over, and if not we can remove this autoscaling group.

cc @konturn @areusch
comments: lgtm--we'll have to run jenkins workflow in ci repo for the fleet change to be propagated of course.

commits.body:
Add ARM-SMALL instance type

Same as in #24 this adds `r6g.large` instances under the
`ARM-SMALL` label so we can start testing and using those in CI (5x
cheaper than `m6g.4xlarge`). If that works well we can convert some
usages over, and if not we can remove this autoscaling group.

pull_request.title: Add CPU-SMALL instances
pull_request.body:
This adds a class of CPU instances that are far [cheaper](https://instances.vantage.sh/?compare_on=true&selected=c4.4xlarge,r5.large) than the current `CPU` instances that we can use for certain tasks that don't require big instances, I'm thinking for linting and builds (since those are mostly cached anyways). We could also potentially move certain test steps to these instances such as the unit tests but reliability.

cc @areusch @konturn

commits.body:
Add CPU-SMALL instances

This adds a class of CPU instances that are far cheaper than the current `CPU` instances that we can use for certain tasks that don't require big instances, I'm thinking for linting and builds (since those are mostly cached anyways). We could also potentially move certain test steps to these instances such as the unit tests but reliability.

pull_request.title: disabled rule 932115 for probate
pull_request.body:
### JIRA link (if applicable) ###

ServiceNow Change Request: CHG5001130

### Change description ###

Probate API calls are getting blocked by WAF due to false-positive detection with certain WAF rules.
The request payloads in such calls are coincidentally containing specific sequences of characters (like post codes in addresses) that resemble keywords/commands in some scripting languages, command sets, etc. WAF is then treating them as suspicious and blocking them.

The preferred solution is to design and implement smarter logic in the WAF rules. In the interest of time and subject to IA approval, we can resolve the issue by disabling the following rules identified by DevOps:
932115 - REQUEST-932-APPLICATION-ATTACK-RCE - Remote Command Execution: Windows Command Injection

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one with "x")

```
[ ] Yes
[X] No
```

commits.body: disabled rule 932115 for probate

Create a custom_data string with Terraform Ouputs

# Overview
Currently, users have the ability to add `custom_data` to a linux VM in two ways:

1. Passing a local path to a script.
2. Directly inserting code in the `tfvars`

This allows users to manually enter `custom_data` for these machines. But it does __not__ allow users to build a a string for the `custom_data` from the outputs of other Terraform outputs.

# Our Use Case
In our use case, we need to set the following string as the `custom_data`:
```
storage-account=stname, access-key=some-secret, file-share=myfileshare, share-directory=testdirectory
```

# Implementation
The implementation isnt exactly the cleanest. It currently requires a nested `if` statement to mimic an `elif` block. In the future is others want to add other dynamically created string for `custom_data`, they will have to add other another loop.

pull_request.title: Mtms - Azure AD Improvements + other for multi-tenant - multi-subscription deployments
pull_request.body:
This PR adds the support for

azuread_applications as a standalone object (not the existing azuread_apps is more opiniated and is not changed)
azuread_credentials add support for azuread applications passwords (certificate not yet covered)
azuread_credential_policies add support for password rotation policy
azuread_service_principals can create a service princpical based on an application_id (see examples/azuread/103-service-principal-only/configuration.tfvars)
azuread_service_principal_passwords is now a standalone object
azuread_service_principals is now supported in role_mapping , keyvault_access_policies and azuread_roles
azuread_service_principals can be deployed in different tfstates and reference remote azuread_applications
subscription billing role can be set to azuread_service_principals

pull_request.title: Developer environment optimisations
pull_request.body:
### What is the context of this PR?
I have optimised the instance sizes and behaviour of the developer defaults to save money by not running excessively sized servers and to not retail data for long periods.

All instances are running at their smaller sizes.
I have run the functional tests and manually gone through surveys and i can't notice any performance impact.

### How to review
Validate that the developer environment still works as expected for you.
comments: Looks good. The commit message should be updated to reflect that it's also adding production defaults and removing unused variables.

commits.body:
Developer environment optimisations
Optimised developer_defaults.tf to reduce cost of running dev environments
Updated default values to match production
Removed unused variable
Updated readme to target git commit rather and tagged version of alexeymedvedchikov.rabbitmq

pull_request.title: Make Python WSGI settings configurable
pull_request.body:
### What is the context of this PR?

The default Elastic Beanstalk settings of 1 process and 15 threads is not very efficient when the size of the instances is increased. This pull request makes the number of processes and number of threads configurable so they can be changed per environment.

### How to review

Customise the `wsgi_number_of_processes` and `wsgi_number_of_threads` variables in your terraform.tfvars file for survey-runner-application and verify the Elastic Beanstalk configuration has been updated (Configuration > Software Configuration) e.g.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1754822/23125699/fda0d51e-f76a-11e6-9915-4811feb9f71a.png)

commits.body:
Make Python WSGI settings configurable

The default Elastic Beanstalk settings of 1 process and 15 threads is
not very efficient when the size of the instances is increased. This
pull request makes the number of processes and number of threads
configurable so they can be changed per environment.

pull_request.title: Added billing account IAM role grant
pull_request.body:
This is the pull request for issue https://github.com/timant-dev/gcp-lz-bootstrap/issues/14
This removes the billing.user role from the org level grant and replaces it with the billing.admin role on the billing account. This allows the seed Terraform service account to grant other Terraform service accounts access to the billing account.

I have tested it by running a bootstrap deployment in a test org.

commits.body: Added billing account IAM role grant

-   Key Vaults are now loaded using [the `ListBySubscription` API within the Key Vault Resource Provider](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/keyvault/keyvault/vaults/list-by-subscription?view=rest-keyvault-keyvault-2022-07-01\&tabs=HTTP) rather than [the Resources API](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/keyvault/keyvault/vaults/list?view=rest-keyvault-keyvault-2022-07-01\&tabs=HTTP). This change means that the Provider now caches the list of Key Vaults available within a Subscription, rather than loading these piecemeal to workaround stale data returned from the Resources API ([#​24019](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24019))

FEATURES:

-   New Data Source: `azurerm_stack_hci_cluster` ([#​24032](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24032))

ENHANCEMENTS:

-   dependencies: updating to `v0.20231129.1103252` of `github.com/hashicorp/go-azure-sdk` ([#​24063](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24063))
-   `automation`: updating to API Version `2023-11-01` ([#​24017](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24017))
-   `keyvault`: the cache is now populated using the `ListBySubscription` endpoint on the KeyVault Resource Provider rather than via the `Resources` API ([#​24019](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24019)).
-   `keyvault`: updating the cache to populate all Key Vaults available within the Subscription to reduce the number of API calls ([#​24019](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24019))
-   Data Source `azurerm_private_dns_zone`: refactoring to use the `ListBySubscription` API rather than the Resources API when `resource_group_name` is omitted ([#​24024](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24024))
-   `azurerm_dashboard_grafana` - support for `grafana_major_version` ([#​24014](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24014))
-   `azurerm_linux_web_app` - add support for dotnet 8 ([#​23893](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/23893))
-   `azurerm_linux_web_app_slot` - add support for dotnet 8 ([#​23893](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/23893))
-   `azurerm_media_transform` -  deprecate `face_detector_preset` and `video_analyzer_preset` ([#​24002](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24002))
-   `azurerm_postgresql_database` - update the validation of `collation` to include `Norwegian_Norway.1252` ([#​24070](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24070))
-   `azurerm_postgresql_flexible_server` - updating to API Version `2023-06-01-preview` ([#​24016](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/24016))
-   `azurerm_redis_cache` - support for the `active_directory_authentication_enabled` property ([#​23976](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/23976))

ENHANCEMENTS:

-   dependencies: updating to `v0.20230511.1094507` of `github.com/hashicorp/go-azure-sdk` ([#​21759](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21759))
-   provider: improving the error messages when parsing a Resource ID and the ID doesn't match what's expected ([#​21725](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21725))
-   provider: Resource Provider Registration now uses API Version `2022-09-01` ([#​21695](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21695))
-   provider: updating the `IsAzureStack` check to use `hashicorp/go-azure-sdk` rather than relying on the environment from `Azure/go-autorest` ([#​21697](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21697))

-   `azurerm_mssql_server` - expose the ability to enable `Transparent Data Encryption` using a `Customer Managed Key` during server deployment ([#​21704](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21704))
-   `azurerm_orbital_contact_profile` - `ip_address` is now optional ([#​21721](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21721))

BUG FIXES:

-   provider: fixing a bug where we would invoke but not poll for the Registration State during automatic Resource Provider Registration ([#​21695](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21695))
-   `azurerm_app_configuration`: handling an API bug where when polling for `PurgeDeleted` returns a 404 rather the payload for a long-running operation ([#​21665](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21665))
-   `azurerm_api_management_api` - fixing a bug where an empty `contact` bug would cause a crash ([#​21740](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21740))
-   `azurerm_eventhub_namespace` - add locks and remove unneeded WaitForState functions ([#​21656](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21656))
-   `azurerm_machine_learning_workspace` - parse `key_vault_id` insensitively ([#​21684](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21684))
-   `azurerm_monitor_action_group` - further expand ExactlyOneOf logic for `event_hub_receiver` attributes ([#​21735](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21735))
-   `azurerm_monitor_metric_alert` - fix regression by using `SingleResourceMultiMetricCriteria` for new metric alerts  ([#​21658](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21658))
-   `azurerm_service_fabric_managed_cluster` - fixing a bug where `certificates` within the `vm_secrets` block wouldn't be set into the state ([#​21680](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21680))
-   `azurerm_storage_share` - correct resource ID segment from `fileshares` to `shares` ([#​21645](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21645))
-   `azurerm_virtual_machine_scale_set`,  - - support specifying `ultra_ssd_disk_iops_read_write` and `ultra_ssd_disk_mbps_read_write` for `PremiumV2_LRS` ([#​21530](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-azurerm/issues/21530))

pull_request.title: Update to Kubernetes 1.16.2
pull_request.body:
- Dependent on https://github.com/kinvolk/terraform-render-bootkube/pull/23
- Update etcd to v3.4.2
- Update the provider versions
- Update the terraform ct provider to 0.4.0
- Update Kubernetes to 1.16.2
- Update Calico to 3.9.2
- Remove labels `node-role.kubernetes.io`, kubelet cannot set these labels using the flag --node-labels. This is enforced as a security feature. But this can be set manually by cluster-admin.
comments:
LGTM, didn't test it myself. I trust the CI :see_no_evil: 

Just a minor comment on the bootkube commit used.

Oh, one **important** thing! 1.16 removes support for several deprecated stuff (https://kubernetes.io/blog/2019/07/18/api-deprecations-in-1-16/). Are we really sure that all compents that are around have been updated? Maybe makes sense to make sure they are tested too...

We probably should **NOT** merge until we are really sure that all the removals in 1.16 don't break anything

Click approved and later realized about the 1.16. I tried to removed the approve but couldn't :-D. EDIT: found it :-D

I want to emphazize we should not merge this until we are absolutely sure that it doesn't break other things using the deprecated stuff. We do not want to have a master we can't use. I'd like to really check that everything works with this before approval :-D

commits.body:
Update the provider versions

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

Update terraform-provider-ct to 0.4.0

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

Change Azure default controller_type and worker_type

* Change default controller_type to Standard_B2s. A B2s is cheaper
by $17/month and provides 2 vCPU, 4GB RAM (vs 1 vCPU, 3.5GB RAM)

* Change default worker_type to Standard_DS1_v2. F1 was the previous
generation. The DS1_v2 is newer, similar cost, more memory, and still
supports Low Priority mode, if desired

This commit was ported from https://github.com/poseidon/typhoon/commit/4a7083d94a6e199091f248f669516109fdbffb47

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

Update Kubernetes version from v1.15.3 to v1.16.1

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

Replace labels `node-role.kubernetes.io` with `node.kubernetes.io`

With Kubernetes v1.16.x kubelet cannot set the labels with prefix
`node-role` in `kubernetes.io` namespace.

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

Update Kubernetes version from v1.16.1 to v1.16.2

Signed-off-by: Suraj Deshmukh <suraj@kinvolk.io>

pull_request.title: Packet: Switch to official Flatcar images from Packet
pull_request.body:
This PR switches from iPXE-booting Flatcar to using official Flatcar images from Packet.

Also fixes https://github.com/kinvolk/lokomotive-kubernetes/issues/27.

**We should merge this only after Flatcar is generally available in all Packet facilities.**

## Testing

At the moment official Flatcar images are available only in the `sjc1` and `nrt1` facilities in preview mode, so this PR can be tested only using these facilities.

Please use the updated [docs](https://github.com/kinvolk/lokomotive-kubernetes/blob/johananl/packet-no-ipxe/docs/flatcar-linux/packet.md) *from this PR* when testing since the PR includes variable changes.
comments: It looks fine, there are some border cases and some functionality (like RAID arrays, to which disk the OS is installed when the server has several, etc.) that we may want to pay special attention. But seems great :)

Looks like @rata's review covered all issues, which are:
- check on which disk the OS is installed
- restore raid building functionality, maybe we move it to ignition config?

I tested it with `lokoctl` and everything seems to work, so LGTM.
LGTM and all my comments seem to have been addressed (haven't tested myself, though) and Packet reported images are available on all regions
Seems OK (didn't test) :+1:
Overall, LGTM. There is a backwards incompatible change (the `/mnt/`mount thing) that we may want to think about before merging, IMHO

LGTM!

I'd love to simplify that logic in the future, though. Maybe we can create an issue? There might be some paths to explore, like adding local disks info to the metadata (`/run/metadata/flatcar`)?

commits.body: Use official Flatcar OS instead of iPXE

Remove os_version and update os_channel

os_version is no longer relevant when using official Flatcar on
Packet since previous versions can no longer be selected.

The OS channel is now specified using the following convention:

`flatcar_<stable|beta|alpha|edge>`
Remove ipxe_script_url var

pull_request.title: Prisoner content hub - prod - Upgrade RDS to t3.xlarge
pull_request.body:
This is to increase the resources for RDS to `xlarge`, as we are seeing errors in RDS related to max_connections.  E.g. 
```
2022-07-22 13:11:39 0 [Warning] Aborted connection 0 to db: 'unconnected' user: 'unauthenticated' host: 'connecting host' (Too many connections)
```

The max_connections configuration is tied to the db instance size.

Note we are **not** increasing the dev and staging environments, as these do not require such a large instance and would be an unnecessary cost.

Related Trello card: https://trello.com/c/EjfBYww7/1315-downtime-post-mortem

commits.body: Upgrade RDS to t3.xlarge

apply_immediately is not a known param

pull_request.title: adding gh actions secrets
pull_request.body:
Have added access to ecr creds to the  analytical-platform-uploader repo to enable automatic deployment of the docker image for the app. Current process is to build and deploy the image from the command line for each significant merge into the repo, which isn't terribly efficient.

Have followed the process outlined in the GitHub Actions section of the cloud platform user guidance [available here](https://user-guide.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/documentation/getting-started/ecr-setup.html#github-actions)

By way of background, the analytical-platform-uploader allows users to upload data to S3 through a web app, automatically creating the s3 buckets and glue schemas in the case of a new database, which is then more widely accessible through the tools provided on the ap and athena.

pull_request.title: IC-2096: Upgrade to a generic purpose DB instance class on interventions/prod
pull_request.body:
_Description added 25 April 2022_

We have decided on `db.m5.large` as the T3 instance class is burstable and we wanted consistency

Additionally, the m5.large has 2 cpu, 8 GB RAM as well as the t3.large but more bandwidth and better network performance in exchange for about 25% increase in cost

db.t3.large	$0.164
db.m5.large	$0.206

For the load around July 2021, we had quite a lot of data going back and forth for dashboard queries, so we wanted consistent load and bandwidth guarantees.

pull_request.title: Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana
pull_request.body:
### What

Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana. This enables the data for Prometheus, and the Grafana configuration to be recovered if the volumes or instances are deleted. The snapshots are created and managed using Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager, which incurs no extra cost (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/snapshot-lifecycle.html).

### Why

It is best practice to have a backup of our data

Link to Jira card (if applicable): 
https://technologyprogramme.atlassian.net/jira/software/projects/GW/boards/251?selectedIssue=GW-858

commits.body:
Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana

This enables the data for Prometheus, and the Grafana configuration to be
recovered if the volumes or instances are deleted. The snapshots are created
and managed using Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager, which incurs no extra cost

pull_request.title: Update low CPU alarm on ECS tasks
pull_request.body:
### What

* Reduce low CPU alarm threshold to 0.3% on staging Auth API and Logging API ECS task alarms.
* Toggle CPU threshold value to adjust for different CPU averages between staging and production.
* Update alarm name and description for clarity

### Why

* The average CPU for both staging ECS tasks is always below 1% (even the max CPU rarely exceeds 1%) therefore these alerts will always go off. The minimum low CPU hovers around 0.3%, in which case we do want to downscale the number of ECS tasks for efficiency and cost savings.
* Production is slightly different. The CPU average rarely dips below 1% so it's sensible to keep the threshold for production at 1%.

[Link to Trello card](https://trello.com/c/XowCI6x0/298-address-cloudwatch-alerts-in-alarm-state).

commits.body:
feat: reduce low CPU alarm threshold

* The average CPU for both ECS tasks is always below 1% (even the max CPU rarely exceeds 1%) therefore these alerts will always go off.
* The minimum low CPU hovers around 0.3%, in which case we do want to downscale the number of ECS tasks.
feat: update alarm name and description for clarity

feat: toggle CPU threshold value for production and staging

* Staging ECS task CPU rarely exceeds 1% but production is different. Low CPU in production hovers just above 1%, if it were to go beneath 1% it's possible we'd want to downscale for efficiency.

pull_request.title: feat: add an S3 bucket to collect metrics
pull_request.body:
# Description
We want a new S3 bucket for our apps to write custom metrics intro, and for us to consume through another app later.

# Discussion
Am I right in thinking that this is enough to get us going? A simple S3 bucket built on the London side of the cloud, namescoped to the correct environment.

When we actually want to write or read in it, we'll simply specify the bucket name in the relevant IAM policies (i.e `govwifi-admin/iam-roles.tf`)?

production.

pull_request.title: Miscellaneous Contributions
pull_request.body: This is an amalgamation of various improvements sourced from the GitHub network graph.

commits.body: Expose more parameters
Expose google instance tags
Parameterize hardcoded resource names
Gitlab runner requires '=' for boolean

grouped and sorted variables more logically

Split variables into Global, Runner and Worker sections.  Within each of
those sorted alphabetically.

tidy up GitLab and GCP naming

The variables name and ci_runner_instance_name were being used but had
some issues.  ci_runner_instance_name was being used to name the runner
in GitLab itself as well as the instance name in GCP.  name was too
generically named and only impacted service accounts in GCP.

The new approach uses the following two variables:

* gcp_resource_prefix - Prefixes all GCP resources
* ci_runner_gitlab_name - Names the registered runner inside GitLab.

change default runner machine type to f1-micro

A previous change set the default runner type to e2-micro in the
mistaken belief that it was cheaper.  It _is_ cheaper per hour but is
more expensive per month due to lack of sustained use discounts.

remove ci_worker_storage_driver variable

This variable was driving the Docker engine-storage-driver parameter.
We don't have a clear use case for allowing this to be set and in most
cases we're going to want Docker to set the default.  As currently
implemented the value was being set from our own variable default rather
than allowing Docker to set its own.  It can be re-introduced if a clear
use case emerges and if it can be implemented in a way where Docker can
choose the default.

remove default runner tags

We're not in a good position to be opinionated about tagging schemes.
parameterise the runner disk size

add descriptions to all variables

A number of recent changes hadn't included descriptions for all
variables so this addresses this issue.

This includes a variable rename from variable ci_runner_untagged to
ci_runner_gitlab_untagged for consistency.
fix escaping in the ci_runner_gitlab_name description

align docker-machine test and worker options

We create a test docker machine during runner creation to make sure
docker machine is fully operational before jobs are executed.  This
change brings the options used for that machine into line with the
machines created for workers during job execution.

pull_request.title: Merge changes from MehrCurry
pull_request.body:
@MehrCurry has some nice changes in his/her repository.

- Allow to set `ci_runner_instance_name`
- increase disk size
- Use VM type `e2-micro`, which is more powerful and a bit cheaper

pull_request.title: Add Examples Directory
pull_request.body:
I've been doing a lot of work independent of the others on this repo and I think it's time to put it somewhere on the main branch of the repo. These are three example deployments I've done, and I'm making a new folder `aws-examples/` to house them. Part of my thought process is in this issue: https://github.com/pangeo-data/terraform-deploy/issues/39

Since these are in a different folder, it shouldn't interfere with anyone's configurations. Let me know if you have thoughts @yuvipanda @jaytmiller @super-cob .

commits.body:
cluster-autoscaler namespace & service acct shouldn't be configurable

We should limit configuration options to things we want users
to change.
Consolidate cluster autoscaler config

Initial commit

Minimal policy set to configure eks cluster with terraform. Several options are presented with comments.
Move IAM credentials generator to its own dir

Remove automatic hub creation from here

That should be done by hubploy
Fixed config for node registration

Changed core nodegroup to be unmanaged

It should work either way, but I thought it would be cleaner if all 3 nodegroup weren't managed. I also get to enable the k8s node-role this way.

Added autotagging

This is for the UW groups' AWS resources. We have deployed an autotagging stack from GorillaStack to help us with billing. These lines help make sure Terraform tags resources the same way so that it doesn't undo changed made by the autotagging infrastructure.

Fixed kubelet_extra_args syntax

Nodes are now spun up with the correct labels and taints, allowing for both autoscaling to and from 0 and spot instance usage.
Correctly create autoscaling tags

Correcting autoscaler policy connetions

Needed both of these set in order for the autoscaler to properly discover autoscaling groups.

Smaller core machine

Note: need to restrict hub.resources.requests.memory to 0.75G, or at least less than 1G

Changed Tags

Since I changed the autotagger to put values to the 'Owner' tag, I am making the same changes here.
Expose Kubernetes version
Update Kubernetes provider
Upgrade kubernetes version

Fix subnet location of core node

For me, this is us-west-2a. Others using this infrastucture on their accounts may have different zones, which is fine. The important thing is that the core node will only ever be in one zone in case you need to replace it.
Add minimal deployment example
Hackweek infrastructure example
Moving my Terraform blog post's supporting files to an example
Remove old merge characters, extra data block
Rename folder to indicate this will be a tutorial
Add ec2 tutorial intro
Add ami search, plug into ec2 instance block
Add outputs
Formatting fixes
Add tfvars files for easy variable input
Remove helm provider

pull_request.title: Increase the lambda timeout to 60s.
pull_request.body:
We had a timeout with it set to 15 seconds. This may need a bit of
tweaking but this should be enough for now.

Any longer and it takes too long to fail and it costs us more.

commits.body:

pull_request.title: Billing mode
pull_request.body:
##### Corresponding Issue(s) or trello card(s):
https://trello.com/c/XIk0O96k/1192-add-billing-method-to-dynamo-module-to-allow-for-provisioned-or-pay-per-request-tables

##### Summary of change(s):
Allows you to select provisioned or pay-per-request billing methods for the table.

There is currently an issue where you can not convert a pay-per-request to provisioned table. Should be fixed in the next release or so of the aws provider. https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-aws/pull/7363

Changing from provisioned to pay-per-request works correctly.

##### Will the change trigger resource destruction or replacement? If yes, please provide justification:

no.

no

yes

yes

pull_request.title: Increase the memory available to the transfer_monitor_lambda
pull_request.body: ## What does this change? We've noticed this lambda failing through timeouts. Upon investigation it appears the lambda has been consistently using its entire allocation of 128MB which suggested that it was insufficiently resourced resulting in it locking up and timing out. After experimentation is seems that 512MB is sufficient to cause the transfer lambda to succeed. See: > [!NOTE] > This has been applied in production to resolve the existing issue as part of testing. ## How to test - [x] Manual testing to ensure that this resource allocation allows the lambda to suceed. - [ ] Deploy to production, do we continue to see failures? ## How can we measure success? This lambda continues to function and report task failures, as well as clearing up the source bucket controlling costs. ## Have we considered potential risks? This change will result in some increased cost but as this lambda runs quite infrequently the cost change is negligible.

commits.body:
Increase the memory available to the transfer_monitor_lambda

We've noticed this lambda failing through timeouts. Upon investigation it appeas the lambda has been conistently using its entire allocation of 128MB which suggested that it was insufficiciently resourced resulting in it locking up and timing out.

After experimentation is seems that 512MB is sufficient to cause the transfer lambda to succeed. This change will result in some increased cost but as this lambda runs quite infrequently the cost change is negligable.
Apply auto-formatting rules

pull_request.title: Bump the resources available to the clamav service
pull_request.body: ## What does this change This change increases the CPU and memory resources available to the clamav archivematica service. We've seen repeated failures in this service, with metrics indicating CPU usage is capping out at 100% on occasion. Failures: Metrics: We hope to mitigate this issue by naively increasing resources to see if it has an impact. Increase to Fargate resources need to meet some [size requirements](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/fargate-tasks-services.html#fargate-tasks-size), and have [associated costs](https://aws.amazon.com/fargate/pricing/). > [!NOTE] > This change will result in a cost increase. > Presuming 720 hours in a month, the calculation is ((hours * cost of 1vCPU * num vCPUs) + (hours * cost of 1GB memory * number of GB)) * number of tasks. > Before: > ((720 * 0.04048 *1) + (720 * 0.004445 * 3) * 2) = $48.35 > After: > ((720 * 0.04048 *2) + (720 * 0.004445 * 4) * 2) = $83.89 ## Who is this change for? This change hopefully reduces manual work for folk working with Archivematica attempting to get things ingested to the storage service.

commits.body: Bump the resources available to the clamav service

pull_request.title: Various improvements to our deployment around resource usage
pull_request.body:
Closes https://github.com/wellcomecollection/archivematica-infrastructure/issues/128

* Add instructions to the bootstrapping doc on configuring the filesystem space to avoid the issue we just had, and instructions on formatting a newly-created EBS volume
* Reduce storage leaks in the storage service code: once a file has been uploaded to the Wellcome storage service, it can be deleted from the Archivematica disks
* Reduce the size of the EBS volume, RDS databases, and ClamAV tasks – we're underutilising them. This will save ~$300/month, or about ~5% of the workflow account bill.

commits.body: Make sure to get this from the /ebs mount
Reduce the size of the RDS instance (again)
Reduce EBS volume sizes; bump storage service image
reduce the size of the ClamAV tasks
Apply auto-formatting rules
Reduce the size of the Gearman task
Add a repo policy to avoid ECR costs getting out-of-hand

pull_request.title: Use gp3 for our persistent EBS volumes
pull_request.body:
It's ~20% cheaper and the 3000 IOPS we previously got as burst are now available as sustained, for free.

I migrated these volumes manually on Friday, and nobody noticed. XD

Closes https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4906

feat(bootstrap): add input `source_root_directory`

A new input source_root_directory allows to have separate bootstrap.xml
files for separate availability zones. With a Panorama, it allows to
have separate dgname and tplname per availability zone.

This appears the only way to configure panos to have different route
next hops for different availability zones.

commit-id:fa21d4c8

in app1_lb add ports 80 and 443

Many users are mainly interested to see whether http and https
application can respond on the app1 spoke vpc. It is a more friendly
test than ssh.

commit-id:d6ef0a84

in app1_ec2 change the VM to bitnami ready-made nginx

The bitnami library offers a ready-made http/https server, which saves
time during testing. On the previous ubuntu image, the path to have
https was unneccessarily bumpy:
- the inbound ssh needed to work
- the user needed ssh/putty locally
- apt update
- apt install ngnix
- for these commands, the outbound also always needed to work, yet
another difficulty.

All these steps are not needed with a ready-made image.

The bitnami image is free of cost as well.

commit-id:b903e3ed

feat(vmseries): add output `network_interfaces`

The output is usable for a Load Balancer Target Group working in `"ip"`
mode instead of the usual `"instance"` mode (the `target_type` input).

The `"ip"` mode is specifically required for panos overlay routing
scenarios. Generally, it is required for loadbalancing any non-primary
interface of a VM on EC2.

pull_request.title: Add configuration of subaccount sandbox
pull_request.body:
Add the configuration of the subaccount with federated assume role.

For the sub-accounts, we allow any user with a MFA token to assume
the roles, and we control who access which role in the root account.

We add the special case for the role/admin in the root account, that
can assume any role without MFA token. This allows run terraform with
assume role to configure the subaccounts.

commits.body:
Allow the billing role to see billing stuff

We forgot the most obvious policy :)
Move root account definition to its own file

Split aws-aim-user files and configure provider

So the submodule is consistent with the other submodules.
Specify the provider would allow later use assumed modules.

We also pass the account id explicitly, and restrict it.

Add module to configure sub accounts

We add a module similar to the root account that would configure:

 - The account alias
 - The policies:
   - RestrictToWhitelistedIPs to avoid usage outside of
     the whitelisted ips
   - AssumeRoleTrustPolicySubAccountWithMFA that would allow
     assume role using MFA from the root account

 - The roles:
   - admin: for admin usage
   - dev: for normal task as poweuser.

The roles require use the MFA token.

We configure the provider with assume role[1], to configure the
resources in the right account. In the first run, we need to use
a different role that is created in the bootstrap of the account
instead of 'admin', because 'admin' role does not exist. Because
that we allow pass the variable `terraform_assume_role`

We do not want to create the 'admin' role outside of terraform
during bootstrap because if we do, it is difficult to import it back.
It is easier to create a different one and delete it later.

The assume role would have problems with the MFA token, which
we explain in the next commit.

[1] https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/aws/#assume-role

Configure sandbox subaccount

Add configuration for the sandbox subaccount.

We get the subaccount id from the pass store.

We create a new hardcoded variable, we might think later about
a more generic way.

Attempt to configure assume role in terraform

The current policy to assume the roles requires
to have STS credentials with MultiFactorAuthPresent for the current
credentials.

But in the current implementation you must run terraform using
credentials with the role `admin`, to be able to access the bucket
with the state and the operations in the root account.

When terraform tries to assume the role for the submodule, it does it
without asking for the MFA credentials, so assume role
fails.

The solution would be to execute the project with the root user
credentials, and then terraform assumes role for but using MFA:
 - Getting the state for S3, using assume role[1]
 - Configure root account, users

The problem is that MFA support is not implemented in terraform[2].
It would require changes in the code [3] to add logic to ask for
the MFA token:

   assumeRoleProvider.SerialNumber = aws.String("arn:awss:iam::246505230303:mfa/hector.rivas+aws.admin@keytwine.com")
   assumeRoleProviderleProvider.TokenProvider = stscreds.StdinTokenProvider

Leaving the code here for reference

[1] https://www.terraform.io/docs/backends/types/s3.html#role_arn
[2] https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/11734
[3] https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-aws/blob/master/aws/auth_helpers.go#L211-L227

Revert "Attempt to configure assume role in terraform"

This reverts commit 3ceffb3c57548bf0cd8c85a09b9196a3fecdd63d.

Use specific terraform-admin role without MFA

We want to be able to run terraform and assume the role without
a MFA token, as terraform does not support MFA (See previous commit).

But we still want the users to require MFA token to be able to
assume any role.

As workaround, we allow the Principal role "admin" to assume any
other role without the MFA token by adding an additional entry
in the statements of the assume role policy.

pull_request.title: [#95612064] aws/gce: Combine sslproxy and router roles
pull_request.body:
Combine the Nginx which does TLS termination and reverse-proxying for the
routers onto the same machines as the routers. The separate `sslproxy`
machines and their associated resources are no longer needed. This means
that:
- the address of the upstream doesn't change like DNS records for ELBs do
- we're not subject to extra network latency/partitions for reverse proxying
- we have a simpler architecture

I've had to FIXME some resources which can't be deleted in a single
Terraform run. We'll need to remove these later after this has been deployed
to any existing environments like CI.

There will be an accompanying PR to alphagov/tsuru-ansible which will need
to be merged at the same time.

---

aws: Remove router-int load balancer

This was used by Ansible on AWS to configure the Nginx sslproxy machines to
reverse-proxy to the routers. The hostname was referenced in the variable
`hipache_host_internal_lb`. We no longer need this since moving Nginx to the
same machines as the router.

Although we might want to revisit this again later when we test one
application talking to another application through the router - which we
wouldn't want to pay external traffic for.

---

I've tested this with a new environment and rolling forwards an existing environment on both AWS and GCE. Depends on alphagov/tsuru-ansible#69 !

Combine the Nginx which does TLS termination and reverse-proxying for the
routers onto the same machines as the routers. The separate `sslproxy`
machines and their associated resources are no longer needed. This means
that:

- the address of the upstream doesn't change like DNS records for ELBs do
- we're not subject to extra network latency/partitions for reverse proxying
- we have a simpler architecture

I've had to FIXME some resources which can't be deleted in a single
Terraform run. We'll need to remove these later after this has been deployed
to any existing environments like CI.

There will be an accompanying PR to alphagov/tsuru-ansible which will need
to be merged at the same time.

gce: Combine sslproxy and router roles

Combine the Nginx which does TLS termination and reverse-proxying for the
routers onto the same machines as the routers. The separate `sslproxy`
machines and their associated resources are no longer needed. This means
that:

- the address of the upstream doesn't change like DNS records for ELBs do
- we're not subject to extra network latency/partitions for reverse proxying
- we have a simpler architecture

I've had to FIXME some resources which can't be deleted in a single
Terraform run. We'll need to remove these later after this has been deployed
to any existing environments like CI.

There will be an accompanying PR to alphagov/tsuru-ansible which will need
to be merged at the same time.

aws: Remove router-int load balancer

This was used by Ansible on AWS to configure the Nginx sslproxy machines to

Although we might want to revisit this again later when we test one

pull_request.title: Template for AWS Costs Role & Policy
pull_request.body:
This template creates the IAM role and policy as described in the [How to Setup AWS Costs with env0](https://docs.env0.com/docs/aws-costs) documentation.
The outputs include the role ARN and External Id for use in configuring the credential in env0.

pull_request.title: Added conditional SSM vpc endpoints
pull_request.body: We currently have a switch to be able to turn on or off the load testing EC2. We decide it was inefficient to have VPC endpoints being deployed and not being used when the load testing bastion is off. Thus we have added a condition for this. We have also refactored the naming of the module to be more reflective of the load testing use case.

commits.body:
Added conditional SSM vpc endpoints

We currently have a switch to be able to turn on or off the load testing
ec2. We decide it was ineffienct to have VPC endpoints being deployed
and not being used when the load testing bastion is off. Thus we have
added a condition for this. We have also refectored the naming of the
module to be more reflective of the load testing use case.

pull_request.title: Introduce separate modules for each destination
pull_request.body:
This PR introduces a separate Terraform module for each log export
destination: bigquery, pubsub, and storage. Having separate modules per
destination allows us to reduce code complexity and will allow for
computed values in the `var.parent_resource_id` input variable (which
fixes issue #10). Output names have remained the same, but input
variables have been added or changed for clarity.
comments: It's great to see extensive test coverage, but the value of the tests is limited because they are essentially verifying that `terraform`, `gcloud`, and `inspec-gcp` can read the same resources. Let's refocus the test suites on the intended behaviour of their associated examples, like triggering a log event and verifying that it is exported to the expected destination.
Each submodule requires a `README.md`. They just need to concisely state the application of the submodule and provide hooks for the inputs and outputs to be generated.

commits.body:
Refactor into destination modules

This commit refactors the existing Terraform module from a single module
to a log export module with submodules for each export destination:
bigquery, pubsub, and storage. Having separate modules per destination
allows us to reduce code complexity and will allow for computed values
in the `var.parent_resource_id` input variable (which fixes issue #10).
Outputs have changed so that each module has its own dedicated output
variables (instead of maps according to export/destination), and
variables have been named so that outputs from one module designed to be
fed to the other module have similar names.  Examples have been provided
for each destination and parent resource type pairing, so there are now
12 examples demonstrating how to configure every destination and log
sink level.

Update files based on module template

Because this module existed before we started using the module template
to define new modules, this commit brings in all common files that
usually come from the module-template that don't currently exist. This
includes files like `Makefile`, `Gemfile`, `test/ci_integration.sh`, and
all necessary supporting files.

Introduce kitchen-terraform tests

This commit includes all changes needed to implement kitchen-terraform
tests for the log-exports module. Tests are structured exactly the same
as examples: folders for each of the destinations, and subfolders for
each log sink level that's possible for each destination (with
billing_account as an exception - more on that later). Each test fixture
functions independently and relies upon environment variables that are
set within `test/ci_integration.sh` (environment variables for the SA
key json, project ID, and the parent resource
project/folder/org/billing_account). Like all the other CFT modules,
tests are invoked based on make targets from `Makefile`, and there are
dedicated targets for testing from the CFT Docker container as well as
directly from your laptop/machine.

A test fixture called `computed_values` has also been provided to
specifically test issue #10 of the log-export module. This test spins up
a project on the fly and passes that computed project ID to the
log-export module to ensure that the module can handle computed values.

Tests for the billing account level log sinks are not provided within this
commit and will be provided in a later commit/PR.

pull_request.title: Upgrade the root volume type to gp3
pull_request.body:
## 🗣 Description ##

This pull request upgrades the root volume type from gp2 to gp3.

## 💭 Motivation and context ##

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are codependent with gp2.

## 🧪 Testing ##

See cisagov/cool-assessment-terraform#148 for an example of how I tested identical changes in another repository.

## ✅ Checklist ##

- [x] This PR has an informative and human-readable title.
- [x] Changes are limited to a single goal - _eschew scope creep!_
- [x] All relevant type-of-change labels have been added.
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](../blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] These code changes follow [cisagov code standards](https://github.com/cisagov/development-guide).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass.

commits.body:
Upgrade the root volume type to gp3

gp3 is cheaper and the baseline configuration offers better
performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the
volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are
codependent with gp2.

Remove delete_on_termination line from config

delete_on_termination = true is the default, so there is no need to
specify it.
Alphabetize entries in root_block_device block

pull_request.title: Independently scale-out frontend, analytics, and metadata
pull_request.body:
## What

Allow us to set the scale of the `number_of_frontend_apps`, `number_of_analytics_apps` and `number_of_metadata_apps` independently from the global `number_of_apps`

## Why

So that we can scale out only the application that requires scaling out and avoid needing to overprovision the ECS cluster size.

## Context

frontend, analytics and metadata apps all live on the same "ingress" ECS cluster with a fixed cluster size, making it tricky to scale out the apps while keeping track of how big the cluster should be.

This changes uses [asg capacity provider](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/cluster-auto-scaling.html#asg-capacity-providers) to automatically scale the "ingress" cluster size based on the desired number of frontend, analytics and metadata app instances configured.

to ensure that two of the same task don't run on the same instance, we use the "spread" placement strategy.

## :warning: Before Merging

* [x] Ensure https://github.com/alphagov/verify-infrastructure-config/pull/285 has been merged FIRST to avoid accidentally scaling down frontend instances in prod!

commits.body:
configurable min/max asg sizes

allow configuring min_size and max_size of ASGs setup via the asg
module.

this is to enable work to move to capacity provider congiured asg sizes.

the desired_capacity config is dropped as terraform defaults this to the
min_size if not present (which is same as before) and keeping this value
set may conflict with capacity provider
add service role for ecs to manage asg

expose arn and name from asg module

...so we can setup dependency with capacity provider

set ingress services to use service linked role

allow service to assume the service linked role for managing ASGs/LBs

let ECS manage the ingress ASG size

the ASG capacity provider lets ECS decide the required size of the ASG
based on the tasks running on the cluster.

this configures a capacity provider for the ingress cluster so that we
can decouple the size of the cluster from the desired number of
frontend, analytics and metadata tasks we want to run on it.

ensure all ecs instances have service linked role

the ECS agents needs to correctly register instances with the capacity
provider, asg, and ecs service. attaching the service linked role to the
instance profile ensure it always has the correct permissions.

"spread" placement for ingress services

we would like for instances/tasks of the same service to execute
seperate EC2 instances to maintain high availability at the cost of less
effcient binpacking.

this is more important now that capacity providers manage the size of
the ECS cluster as we want it to prefur scaling up to more instances
than packing more tasks onto an already busy node.

scale frontend/analytics/metadata indepentantly

previously the number of instances of each application was set from a
single variable number_of_apps making it harder to scale each app
seperatly

this breaks out the frontend, analytics, and metadata app scaling into
seperate vars number_of_frontend_apps, number_of_analytics_apps and
number_of_metadata_apps ... allowing each to be tuned indepentantly

the ingress ECS cluster that they run on will auto-scale between 2 and
20 EC2 nodes as required to fit the requested number of frontend,
analytics and metadata tasks.

pull_request.title: AUT-606: Update to support xlarge for frontend apps
pull_request.body:
This change

- adds a new task definition for Verify Frontend used in t3.xlarge instance type so that it can use more CPU and memory units.
- adds a conditional statement to ensure that it uses number of EC2 efficiently. This change is required because t3.xlarge supports 4 network interfaces whereas t3.medium supports 3 network interfaces. There are four different containers (analytics, frontend, metadata and beat-exporter). Each container needs a network interface to work properly. So t3.xlarge can support 4 containers whereas t3.medium supports 3 containers. That's why we do not need to double the number of EC2 instances for t3.xlarge.
- adds a conditional statement to ensure that it uses correct task definition for verify fontend for instance type. If the instance type is t3.xlarge, verify frontend app and its ngnix will have more CPU and memory units. If it is not t3.xlarge, verify frontend and its nginx will remain unchanged.
- replaces the generic variable `instance_type` with specific variable `ingress_instance_type`. This change allows us to choose instance type for applications running in ingress cluster only in different environment.

Other applications (e.g. metadata, analytics and beat-exporter) will remain unchanged. This change is needed for reducing the frontend application's CPU usage.

Co-authored-by: Phillip Miller <phillip.miller@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

commits.body:
AUT-606: Update to support xlarge for frontend apps

This change

- adds a new task definition for Verify Frontend used in t3.xlarge instance type so that it can use more CPU and memory units.
- adds a conditional statement to ensure that it uses number of EC2 efficiently. This change is required because t3.xlarge supports 4 network interfaces whereas t3.medium supports 3 network interfaces. There are four different containers (analytics, frontend, metadata and beat-exporter). Each container needs a network interface to work properly. So t3.xlarge can support 4 containers whereas t3.medium supports 3 containers. That's why we do not need to double the number of EC2 instances for t3.xlarge.
- adds a conditional statement to ensure that it uses correct task definition for verify fontend for instance type. If the instance type is t3.xlarge, verify frontend app and its ngnix will have more CPU and memory units. If it is not t3.xlarge, verify frontend and its nginx will remain unchanged.
- replaces the generic variable `instance_type` with specific variable `ingress_instance_type`. This change allows us to choose instance type for applications running in ingress cluster only in different environment.

Other applications (e.g. metadata, analytics and beat-exporter) will remain unchanged. This change is needed for reducing the frontend application's CPU usage.

Co-authored-by: Phillip Miller <phillip.miller@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

pull_request.title: HAProxy TLS termination
pull_request.body:
Context
-------

We need to present the user's source IP to frontend and analytics in order for the billing and audit system, as well as the analytics system.

HAProxy currently proxies the TCP connection it receives from the NLB to the ALB (in order for us to have managed static IP at ingress). However this means the source IP is the IP of HAproxy and not the user.

What
----

- New Docker image static-ingress-tls which is HAProxy but does TLS and HTTP (we still use the other one for forwarding to the ALB for 301s).

- Use the new static-ingress-tls image for HTTPS ingress

- Configure the NLB to treat static-ingress-https target group as a TLS upstream (rather than TCP)

- Configure the NLB to terminate TLS on port 443

How to review
------------

- Code review

commits.body:
Use static-ingress-tls image

Make NLB do TLS by using the new static-ingress-tls image

See d85f0cd

Signed-off-by: Toby Lorne <toby.lornewelch-richards@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

allow static-ingress roles to access both images

Signed-off-by: Toby Lorne <toby.lornewelch-richards@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

Update terraform/modules/hub/static_ingress.tf

pull_request.title: Fast stage contracts via vars
pull_request.body:
This implements stage contracts using regular variables.

It also

- changes output files to be producer instead of consumer driven
- avoids passing initial variables (org, billing, etc.) via stage 00, as they already are in a format that can be consumed directly by other stages

The resulting layout is something like

stage00

```
├── 00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars -> ~/config/tfvars/00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars
├── 00-bootstrap-providers.tf -> ~/config/providers/00-bootstrap-providers.tf
├── automation.tf
├── billing.tf
[...]
```

stage01

```
├── 00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars -> ~/config/tfvars/00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars
├── 00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars.json -> ~/config/tfvars/00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars.json
├── 01-resman.auto.tfvars -> ~/config/tfvars/01-resman.auto.tfvars
├── 01-resman-providers.tf -> ~/config/providers/01-resman-providers.tf
├── billing.tf
├── branch-networking.tf
[...]
```

stage02

```
.
├── 00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars -> ~/config/tfvars/00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars
├── 00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars.json -> ~/config/tfvars/00-bootstrap.auto.tfvars.json
├── 01-resman.auto.tfvars -> ~/config/tfvars/01-resman.auto.tfvars
├── 01-resman.auto.tfvars.json -> ~/config/tfvars/01-resman.auto.tfvars.json
├── 02-networking-providers.tf -> ~/config/providers/02-networking-providers.tf
├── data
│   ├── cidrs.yaml
[...]
```

Files ending in `.tfvars` above are the stage's manual variables, those ending in `.json` are the actual contract and are automatically created.
