pull_request.title: Add an example for updating .terraform.lock.hcl
pull_request.body:
I added an example for updating `.terraform.lock.hcl`.
For details, see: https://github.com/minamijoyo/tfupdate/issues/32

An example for Pull Request generated by this branch can be found in https://github.com/minamijoyo/tfupdate-circleci-example/pull/124

commits.body:
Add an example for updating .terraform.lock.hcl

Terraform v0.14 will introduce a dependency lock file named
`.terraform.lock.hcl`.
https://discuss.hashicorp.com/t/terraform-0-14-the-dependency-lock-file/15696

The lock file is an implementation detail and it's hard to update it
with the tfupdate command. Because the hash value format seems to allow
future terraform versions to change the hash algorithm gradually. If
tfupdate updates the lock file, it will be difficult to support multiple
terraform versions without an unexpected the lock file drift.

Perhaps a recommended way is to use the terraform command to update the
lock file. However most CIs use linux and laptops may be mac or windows
and if you run terraform on multiple platforms, it requires to generate
hashed for all platforms to avoid a lock file drift. So I added an
example for it, but I found it's inefficient because it requires
duplicate downloads for providers on init. I tried to use a plugin cache
dir or a local filesystem mirror, but I couldn't figure out a way to
avoid duplicate downloads on init. If I use cache or mirror, it doesn't
record zip hashes, and it records them only when download providers from
origin. I think the easiest way to use Terraform v0.14 with tfupdate is
adding .terraform.lock.hcl to .gitignore.
Update Terraform to v0.14.0

pull_request.title: (#38) Update project and vpc modules to TF 13
pull_request.body:
This patch upgrades the CFT Project Factory and Network modules for use
with Terraform 13.

Closes: #38

commits.body:
(#38) First update to latest 0.12 versions

Apply these versions with TF 0.12 and then TF 0.13 to avoid the
following error.

```
Error: Provider configuration not present

To work with
module.host.module.project.module.project-factory.null_resource.preconditions
its original provider configuration at
provider["registry.terraform.io/-/null"] is required, but it has been removed.
This occurs when a provider configuration is removed while objects created by
that provider still exist in the state. Re-add the provider configuration to
destroy
module.host.module.project.module.project-factory.null_resource.preconditions,
after which you can remove the provider configuration again.
```

Changes are expected:

```
An execution plan has been generated and is shown below.
Resource actions are indicated with the following symbols:
  - destroy

Terraform will perform the following actions:

  # module.host.module.project.module.project-factory.null_resource.preconditions will be destroyed
  - resource "null_resource" "preconditions" {
      - id       = "8839499245402532934" -> null
      - triggers = {
          - "billing_account"  = "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX"
          - "credentials_path" = ""
          - "folder_id"        = "folders/XXXXXXXXXXXX"
          - "org_id"           = "XXXXXXXXXXXX"
          - "shared_vpc"       = ""
        } -> null
    }

Plan: 0 to add, 0 to change, 1 to destroy.

Do you want to perform these actions in workspace "dev"?
  Terraform will perform the actions described above.
  Only 'yes' will be accepted to approve.

  Enter a value: yes

module.host.module.project.module.project-factory.null_resource.preconditions: Destroying... [id=8839499245402532934]
module.host.module.project.module.project-factory.null_resource.preconditions: Destruction complete after 0s
```

(#38) Update to project factor 10.x and network 3.x for TF 13

Also run `terraform 0.13upgrade` to generate version information.

Fix multiregion example autoscaling when num_instances=0

Without this patch autoscaling is enabled even when running
`num_instances=0` with the multiregion example.

Upgrade to Terraform 0.13

Fix the following warning with 0.13.6

```
Warning: Interpolation-only expressions are deprecated

  on ../../modules/50_compute/main.tf line 33, in data "template_file" "startup-script-config":
  33:   template = "${file("${path.module}/templates/startup-script-config.tpl")}"

Terraform 0.11 and earlier required all non-constant expressions to be
provided via interpolation syntax, but this pattern is now deprecated. To
silence this warning, remove the "${ sequence from the start and the }"
sequence from the end of this expression, leaving just the inner expression.

Template interpolation syntax is still used to construct strings from
expressions when the template includes multiple interpolation sequences or a
mixture of literal strings and interpolations. This deprecation applies only
to templates that consist entirely of a single interpolation sequence.
```

pull_request.title: Autoscaler
pull_request.body:
* Setup iperf on endpoints for autoscale testing
 * Configure endpoints in the same zone to reduce zone egress network costs.
 * Switch endpoints to Debian 10 for iperf2 multi-client support
 * Run iperf directly from the startup script, it was misbehaving when run from systemd.
 * Run 180 sequential iperf runs, 10 seconds each to create persistent upward pressure on the autoscaler and TCP window sizes.
 * Add role label with value of multinic-endpoint, iperf-client, or iperf-server to help build charts in the Monitoring console.
 * Set max replicas per zone to 6

Resolves: https://github.com/openinfrastructure/terraform-google-multinic/issues/16

commits.body:
Autoscaler

 * Setup iperf on endpoints for autoscale testing
 * Configure endpoints in the same zone to reduce zone egress network
   costs.
 * Switch endpoints to Debian 10 for iperf2 multi-client support
 * Run iperf directly from the startup script, it was misbehaving when
   run from systemd.
 * Run 180 sequential iperf runs, 10 seconds each to create persistent
   upward pressure on the autoscaler and TCP window sizes.
 * Add role label with value of multinic-endpoint, iperf-client, or
   iperf-server to help build charts in the Monitoring console.
 * Set max replicas per zone to 6

pull_request.title: Temporary fix for NAT setup (increase in billing)
pull_request.body:
**NOTE: this hasn't been tested with an existing cluster yet**

Our latest ECS cluster configuration adds a private subnet layer that talks to the pubic subnet using a NAT gateway. Since AWS charges NAT gateway by the hour, it impacts in an additional cost of 35~40 dollars per gateway, which is not needed in most cases. This is not a final config, but it's an intermediary step, that can be applied to existing clusters without much impact.

pull_request.title: feat(vpc): Optionally use NAT instances instead of NAT gateways
pull_request.body:
IF NAT instances are used, optional inputs are whether to use Elastic

gateways for development VPCs. NAT instances can be stopped when not in
use.

IF NAT instances are used, optional inputs are whether to use Elastic
IPs, an SSH key name, and the EC2 instance type. The latest Amazon VPC
NAT AMI is used. The use of NAT instances can be less expensive than NAT

vpc: ignore new AMIs, remove associate_public_ip_address from NAT instances

New Amazon NAT AMIs are now ignored - this previously caused NAT instances
to be recreated.

NAT instances no longer use associate_public_ip_address, as this caused
instances which were not using an Elastic IP Address to be
recreated if Terraform was run while NAT instances were stopped.

pull_request.title: Add random_page_cost param custom value
pull_request.body:
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of a non-sequentially-fetched
disk page. The default is 4.0. This value can be overridden for tables
and indexes in a particular tablespace by setting the tablespace
parameter of the same name (see sql-altertablespace).

Reducing this value relative to seq_page_cost will cause the system to
prefer index scans; raising it will make index scans look relatively
more expensive. You can raise or lower both values together to change
the importance of disk I/O costs relative to CPU costs, which are
described by the following parameters.
ref. https://postgresqlco.nf/doc/en/param/random_page_cost/

#### Summary
Add random_page_cost param custom value

#### Ticket Link
https://mattermost.atlassian.net/browse/MM-32388

#### Release Note
```release-note
Adds random_page_cost param custom value
```

commits.body:
Add random_page_cost param custom value

Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of a non-sequentially-fetched
disk page. The default is 4.0. This value can be overridden for tables
and indexes in a particular tablespace by setting the tablespace
parameter of the same name (see sql-altertablespace).

Reducing this value relative to seq_page_cost will cause the system to
prefer index scans; raising it will make index scans look relatively
more expensive. You can raise or lower both values together to change
the importance of disk I/O costs relative to CPU costs, which are
described by the following parameters.
ref. https://postgresqlco.nf/doc/en/param/random_page_cost/
Attached a policy so the payment-lambda can update Users' numDapps attributes

pull_request.title: Grant AdminUpdateUserAttributes to payment lambda
pull_request.body: The Payment Lambda can't update the user's Dapp counts if it can't update any UserAttributes.  This PR grants that permission by attaching an existing policy, one which exclusively grants that permission, to the payment lambda's existing IAM role.

pull_request.title: Support `instance_count = 0`
pull_request.body:
Fix error when creating 0 instances

Why would anyone want to create zero instances?

Suppose there are templates being re-used for multiple environments, and in a development or test environment, multiple major application roles/functions (let's call them "foo" and "bar") are handled by a single instance to save on costs. In production, however, each major application role lives on its own instance(s) for better resiliency.

Since Terraform doesn't support conditional invocation of modules, specifying an `instance_count` of `0` for "foo" and "bar" in dev/test and an `instance_count` of `1` for "foobar", while specifying an `instance_count` of `1` for "foo" and "bar", respectively, and `0` for "foobar" in Production, would permit reuse across environments and avoid a lot of copy-paste that may drift.

**Note:** The SSM document association portion was the only part of this template that was currently producing errors, so it's the only one I addressed. This will technically still create all of the other base resources like roles, iam policies, etc. We can tie those to `instance_count` as well, if desired.

pull_request.title: Break up Prometheus instances
pull_request.body:
We currently have a single Prometheus instance per cluster, which
monitors cluster health, application health, and service health (ie
Istio). This Prometheus instance sends alerts to AlertManager and can
send metrics to an AWS Prometheus workspace for longer term metrics
storage and analysis. Prometheus Adapter talks to this instance for
pod autoscaling.

For a small cluster, this setup resulted in the following usage:

* 10% of one vCPU
* 600-700MiB RAM
* 50,000 metrics ingested per scrape

This results in heavy resource usage, expensive long-term storage, and
Prometheus instance that will require GiB of RAM at moderate scale.

In this change, the Prometheus instance is split into three:

* One instance to monitor cluster and pod health (kube-prometheus-stack)
* One instance to monitor Flightdeck and applications (flightdeck)
* One instance to collect aggregated metrics (federated)

The kube-prometheus-stack instance is used only for monitoring and
alerting about cluster and resource health.

The flightdeck instance is used for monitoring and alerting Flightdeck
and (optionally) applications, as well as pod autoscaling.

The federated instance scrapes aggregated metrics from other instances.
Metrics from this instance can be sent for long term storage.

For the same cluster, this setup requires the following usage:

* 5% of one vCPU, split up among three pods
* 600-700MiB RAM, split up among three pods
* 90 metrics ingested per scrape

This results in lower over all cluster resource usage, now distributed
to avoid a single point of failure and make it easier to distribute
loads as the cluster scales.

It sends vastly fewer metrics upstream for ingestion, resulting in lower
long-term storage costs.

It also provides a generic instance for federation, making it possible
to add other Prometheus instances which can then be aggregated and
ingested.

Resolves #50.

commits.body:
Break up Prometheus instances

We currently have a single Prometheus instance per cluster, which
monitors cluster health, application health, and service health (ie
Istio). This Prometheus instance sends alerts to AlertManager and can
send metrics to an AWS Prometheus workspace for longer term metrics
storage and analysis. Prometheus Adapter talks to this instance for
pod autoscaling.

For a small cluster, this setup resulted in the following usage:

* 10% of one vCPU
* 600-700MiB RAM
* 50,000 metrics ingested per scrape

This results in heavy resource usage, expensive long-term storage, and
Prometheus instance that will require GiB of RAM at moderate scale.

In this change, the Prometheus instance is split into three:

* One instance to monitor cluster and pod health (kube-prometheus-stack)
* One instance to monitor Flightdeck and applications (flightdeck)
* One instance to collect aggregated metrics (federated)

The kube-prometheus-stack instance is used only for monitoring and
alerting about cluster and resource health.

The flightdeck instance is used for monitoring and alerting Flightdeck
and (optionally) applications, as well as pod autoscaling.

The federated instance scrapes aggregated metrics from other instances.
Metrics from this instance can be sent for long term storage.

For the same cluster, this setup requires the following usage:

* 5% of one vCPU, split up among three pods
* 600-700MiB RAM, split up among three pods
* 90 metrics ingested per scrape

This results in lower over all cluster resource usage, now distributed
to avoid a single point of failure and make it easier to distribute
loads as the cluster scales.

It sends vastly fewer metrics upstream for ingestion, resulting in lower
long-term storage costs.

It also provides a generic instance for federation, making it possible
to add other Prometheus instances which can then be aggregated and
ingested.

pull_request.title: Disable annotations/labels in logs by default
pull_request.body:
Fluent Bit can add the pod annotations and labels to log output which makes it possible to find and aggregate logs by labels. While this could be useful, it creates extremely large log entries, which can be expensive in Cloudwatch.

This removes most of the Kubernetes metadata from the log output. It leaves namespace, container name, and pod name, which makes it possible to filter by a particular application or process.

commits.body:
Disable annotations/labels in logs by default

Fluent Bit can add the pod annotations and labels to log output which
makes it possible to find and aggregate logs by labels. While this could
be useful, it creates extremely large log entries, which can be
expensive in Cloudwatch.

This removes most of the Kubernetes metadata from the log output. It
leaves namespace, container name, and pod name, which makes it possible
to filter by a particular application or process.

pull_request.title: Develop -> Master for 8.0.0 release
pull_request.body:
Merge `develop` to `master` to create `8.0.0` release.
It has been quite a while since the progress in `develop` was synced to `master`.

There are some major features that come with this new release:


### major features

- terraform v1.1.X support 
  - #818
- support/fixes for S/4 HANA 1909 / 2020 / 2021
  - #808
- create a HANA DB backup after the initial "Netweaver / S/4HANA import"
  - #811 
  - https://github.com/SUSE/sapnwbootstrap-formula/pull/95

#### Azure

- add ANF (Azure Netapp Files) shared storage support for Netweaver and HANA
  - #733 
- add HANA Scale-Out scenario
  - #734 
- add native fencing
  - #714 

#### GCP

- load-balancer instead of routes for drbd/netweaver (new default, same as HANA)
  - **breaking change**: look at `terraform.tfvars.example` how IPs changed
  - #793 

#### Libvirt

- optional cloud-init
  - #824  

#### Openstack

- add HANA Scale-Out scenario
  - #796 

### some minor features/fixes (excerpt)
- improve documentation
  - #735 
  - #744 
- multiple fixes/improvements to prometheus/grafana monitoring setup
  - #710 
  - #726 
  - #750 
  - #788
- refactor qa_mode
  - #772 
- many other smaller fixes

pull_request.title: hana: allow to set ignore min mem check
pull_request.body:
This PR adds a terraform variable to allow to ignore the min memory limitations in hana. This is specially useful for development environments which rely on the `libvirt` terraform provider.

The issue was reported in https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1185643
comments:
@rtorrero Nice!
Some few details:
- Change the PR from `master` to `develop`
- We need to expand this to the other providers (gcp, azure, aws, openstack). You simply need to copy/paste what you did for them
- Add the new variable example in the `terraform.tfvars.example`, under the HANA chapter. You can put more or less the same description ot the variable. It turns out that the users don't really check the variables.tf content, so we need to double the content in the examples files. THis should be done for all the providers too

Hey @rtorrero ,
I noticed that one part is missing here. We are not passing the variable to the grains. For that we need to the next:
1. Add the variable in the outputs. Here: https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/blob/master/generic_modules/common_variables/outputs.tf#L43
2. Add the variable in the output string. Here: https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/blob/master/generic_modules/common_variables/outputs.tf#L110

Finally, add the same `if` condition for the cost-optimized installation too: https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/blob/34a3d5f06238f00ea9a278d7577366fe4845ae37/pillar_examples/automatic/hana/hana.sls#L121

@rtorrero Great! Nice job.
If you have tested and works it is ready to be merged.

pull_request.title: GCP - Increase the NAT mininum nuamber of ports for the bastion - Monitoring PAYG fixed
pull_request.body:
If you PAYG images are used, the deployment fails due the lack of connection ports to get the packages from SCC. This is due the low number of `minimum ports per VM` of the NAT resource. Increasing this value fixes the issue.

Now the value is configurable.

Fix for:https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/issues/693

FYI: @ab-mohamed

**Edit**: The 2nd commit (https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/pull/694/commits/c9e8a124c4c9dcc443a0be6ca0e6a9a0a0e21c44) fixes the Monitoring and iSCSI machines deployment when the bastion host is used and the other machines are using PAYG images

pull_request.title: Develop
pull_request.body:
Merge `develop` in `master` to create the new `7.0.0` version.

Some changes:
- Unify the OS selection to `os_image`
- Set PAYG as default images
- Improve the project to use S4/HANA
- Improve SSH keys management (now, plain SSH keys content can be used too)
- Improve bastion usage for Azure. Now, the monitoring server is bypassed with nginx
- Use the latest terraform azure/gcp/aws resources (matching the ones shipped in SLE)
- And as always, more bugfixing and variables improvement. 

I will detail all the new variables and changes in the release description.

FYI @juadk and @ldevulder There will be some required changes in your openQA tests if you want to adopt this new version (which looks the best as we won't be able to continue adding changes to `6.x.x` codestream)

pull_request.title: Feature/add common variables
pull_request.body:
We have added a lot of new variables, that  are mainly used to render the salt pillar files. With this PR, we move most of the HANA/Netweaver variables from all the modules of all providers in the "common_variables" module. 
With this we will get:

- `common_variables` module contain most of the hana/nw variables for all providers and one place to configure
- The grains will be the same for this topic, avoiding issues like ("I have forgotten to add this variable to this cloud provider")
- We reduce the duplicated code in the `salt_provisioner.tf` files
- We wouldn't have any change for the user

In addition to common variables. I have renamed some variables to be consistent in all providers:
- libvirt variable `hana_inst_media` to `hana_inst_master`
- gcp variable `sap_hana_deployment_bucket` to `hana_inst_master`


Below is variables added to common variables:
`HANA:`
  hana_sid              
  hana_instance_number             
  hana_cost_optimized_sid           
  hana_cost_optimized_instance_number 
  hana_master_password              
  hana_cost_optimized_master_password 
  hana_primary_site                  
  hana_secondary_site                
  hana_inst_master                   
  hana_inst_folder                  
  hana_fstype                       
  hana_platform_folder            
  hana_sapcar_exe                  
  hana_archive_file                
  hana_extract_dir                 
  scenario_type                      
  hana_cluster_vip                   
  hana_cluster_vip_secondary         
  hana_ha_enabled                    
  hana_cluster_fencing_mechanism    
  sbd_storage_type

`Netweaver:`

netweaver_sid                      
  ascs_instance_number                
  ers_instance_number                 
  pas_instance_number                 
  netweaver_master_password          
  netweaver_product_id                
  netweaver_inst_folder               
  netweaver_extract_dir              
  netweaver_swpm_folder              
  netweaver_sapcar_exe               
  netweaver_swpm_sar                 
  netweaver_sapexe_folder           
  netweaver_additional_dvds          
  netweaver_nfs_share               
  hana_ip                          
  netweaver_hana_sid               
  netweaver_hana_instance_number   
  netweaver_hana_master_password   
  netweaver_ha_enabled            
  netweaver_cluster_fencing_mechanism
  netweaver_sbd_storage_type
comments:
I'm not sure if this logically is correct.

e.g `common_variables` are imho `host` releated variables.

If we add `hana/nw` the category becomes more ambigous

we should rename `common_variable` to `common_cloud_variables` or `sap_common_variables`. or related

Right now the `common_variable` is empty like `utils`, it is a bad naming

@Simranpal I still think that we can add more variables to the `common_variables`, like
- `hana_cluster_vip`
- `hana_cluster_vip_secondary`
- `ha_enabled`
- `fencing_mechanism`
- `sbd_storage_type`

We can use these variables in the modules again, as we do with the current common_variables.
At the end, the goal is to unify the variables among the providers to avoid duplicated code and issues maintaining this.
@Simranpal In general looks fine, but I have added some additional comments.

pull_request.title: Feature/s4hana new variables
pull_request.body:
Implement the usage of S/4HANA 1909.
Some items:
- Tune the pillar files almost completely from terraform variables. I think this is the best choice as passing some variables and not other is causing confusion. By now, this is the best approach in my opinion. We can find a better code solution maybe later to avoid having so many code duplicated.
- Adapt the pillar files to use terraform variables data
- Adapt the pillar files to install S/4HANA. I don't have any documentation about the used new variables in the pillar file. It has been a long try/fail process, to find out which are the correct parameters, as there is not any information in the internet unfortunately.
- Adapt the pillar files to deploy properly the non HA scenarios, and scenarios where the NW ASCS and PAS are running in the same machine (apparently a quite standard scenario in small organizations).

New variables for the user:
- hana_sid
- hana_cost_optimized_sid
- hana_instance_number
- hana_cost_optimized_instance_number
- hana_master_password
- hana_cost_optimized_master_password
- hana_primary_site
- hana_secondary_site
- netweaver_app_server_count
- netweaver_ascs_instance_number
- netweaver_ers_instance_number
- netweaver_pas_instance_number
- netweaver_master_password

Depends on:
https://github.com/SUSE/salt-shaptools/pull/73
https://github.com/SUSE/sapnwbootstrap-formula/pull/67/

Thanks @arbulu89 I have some minor suggestions in mainly documentation.

pull_request.title: Feature/redo os image usage
pull_request.body:
Some new implementations to the mechanism used to select the OS image for the machines.

It brings:

- Use PAYG images by default. We receive some issues because the users use default values (BYOS) and they don't have (or don't use) the registration code. For newcomers (or the most standard user), PAYG are better.
- Create new os_image variable as default OS image. Right now, we need to set the OS image for all of the nodes (hana, iscsi, etc). As most of the users will use the same OS for all the machines, having this option makes things easier, as you only need to change 1 variable. Specific customization is still possible of course.
- Unify naming. Now, all the variables for all providers follow the same syntax (`*_os_image).
- Change how Azure images are selected. I think that is easier to only have unique variable, instead of 4, that can be obtained from CLI commands output
- Reformat the terraform.tfvars.example to be more informative (I think I will split this file in terraform.tfvars.example.basic and terraform.tfvars.example.advanced in the future)

FYI @peteratsuse
comments: @arbulu89 I have doubt about the `os_image` if we should add the example usage  of setting sku, version etc. Other than that some typos and corrections in variable description and terraform.tfvars.example. I made the suggestions in `aws/terraform.tfvars.example` but it should apply to other modules
Thanks for the changes @arbulu89 looks good!

commits.body: Set PAYG as default image for AWS and reorganize example file
Set PAYG as default image for GCP and reorganize variables names and example file
Redo how the Azure images data is used and set PAYG as default
Define default os_image and unify naming
Correct typos and improve descriptions

pull_request.title: Feature/on destroy
pull_request.body:
Feature for: https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/issues/405

Coming back again to the `on_destroy` functionality. After exposing the issues in https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/pull/408 I have decided the implement other approach.

I have created the `on_destroy` terraform module. I have implemented there the whole logic, and taking advantage of the `trigger` object, that I basically use to store the information to be used later as `self.triggers`. This way, we can connect to all the machines as we do during the creation.

The `on_depends` parameter is used to avoid the destroying of resources that are needed to keep the SSH connection used by the provisioner.

I have tested in all of the providers (PAYS images in Azure included) and everything worked fine.
comments: @arbulu89 there is one thing I don't quite understand: how is this related to salt? It doesn't look like it executes anything with salt, but it's placed along with the salt provisioner? why is that? also why do we need the salt provisioner enabled to execute this?
LGTM. Didn't test, but the changes make sense.

commits.body:
Add on_destroy scripts to unregister from SCC

https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/issues/405
Create on_destroy module to operations during destroy
Implement on_destroy for libvirt
Implement on_destroy for gcp
Implement on_destroy for azure
Implement on_destroy for aws

Use on_destroy.sh from its terraform module

pull_request.title: Change instance type for SAP certified systems
pull_request.body:
This PR changes all instance type default value to systems certified by SAP.

Recommendations found [here](https://www.sap.com/dmc/exp/2014-09-02-hana-hardware/enEN/iaas.html#) (Certified and supported SAP HANA Hardware Directory)

I choose systems with filter `Clustering = yes`

**AWS**:
 r3.8xlarge - [SAP Certified IaaS Platforms for AWS](https://www.sap.com/dmc/exp/2014-09-02-hana-hardware/enEN/iaas.html#categories=Amazon%20Web%20Services)

**GCP**:
 n1-highmem-32 - [SAP Certified IaaS Platforms for GCP](https://www.sap.com/dmc/exp/2014-09-02-hana-hardware/enEN/iaas.html#categories=Google%20Cloud%20Platform)

**Azure**: 
Standard_M128s - [SAP Certified IaaS Platforms for Azure](https://www.sap.com/dmc/exp/2014-09-02-hana-hardware/enEN/iaas.html#categories=Microsoft%20Azure)

TODO:


- [x] Waiting feedback about chosen instance type

- [x] Update README to warn the user that instance type is configured for production, that means cost could be very expensive and should be change for testing purpose.

pull_request.title: Salt rework for AWS
pull_request.body:
New provisioning way for AWS by using SALT instead bash script.

The deployment consists on using terraform to deploy the infrastructure and salt to provision the machines and manage SAP HANA software.

Currently, only the HA cluster deployment is working. The HANA formula doesn't work due to a dependency issue in Factory repo, it will be fixed asap.
A lot of things could be improve so let me know what do you think about that!

Obviously, it's still a work in progress.

Tested and it works correctly. There is a bug on crmsh older than SLE-12-SP4 that blocks the join of the secondary node, but it is not caused by this PR and we will fix this via MU.

Very well done @juadk and @arbulu89
@juadk could you add a link to the `pillar_examples` folder in the `README` file within `aws/terraform_salt` (section Provisioning by Salt)

2. azure_role_assignment to "Storage blob Data Contributor" for hub-pa-fe as in https://github.com/pagopa/gitops/blob/main/azure-devops/projects/io-pay-projects/io-pay.tf#L210

pull_request.title: Upgrade volumes to gp3
pull_request.body:
## 🗣 Description ##

This pull request:
- Upgrades disk volume types to gp3
- Removes the `delete_on_termination = true` line from `root_block_device` blocks since that is already the default

## 💭 Motivation and context ##

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are intertwined with gp2.

Also note that the volume upgrades are done in place by Terraform, so this change does not result in any instance replacements that must be worked around to avoid disrupting running assessments.

## 🧪 Testing ##

I successfully applied these changes to env1 in our staging COOL environment.

## ✅ Checklist ##

- [x] This PR has an informative and human-readable title.
- [x] Changes are limited to a single goal - _eschew scope creep!_
- [x] All relevant type-of-change labels have been added.
- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](../blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md) document.
- [x] These code changes follow [cisagov code standards](https://github.com/cisagov/development-guide).
- [x] All new and existing tests pass.
comments: Nifty!
Please enjoy all of my attribute order suggestions 🍻

commits.body:
Upgrade all volume types to gp3

gp3 is 20% cheaper, and the baseline configuration offers better
performance than gp2 for volumes smaller than 2TB.  It also allows the
volume size and IOPS to be configured separately, whereas the two are
intertwined with gp2.

Remove delete_on_termination line from config

delete_on_termination = true is the default, so there is no need to
specify it.
Alphabetize entries in root_block_device block

## 🗣 Description

This PR adds conditions to various security group rules so that they are only created if the instance type(s) they apply to (e.g. `kali`, `debiandesktop`, `pentestportal`, etc.) exist in the environment.  

I also did a little splat syntax removal while I was in here, because I know how happy it makes @jsf9k.  

## 💭 Motivation and Context

While working in a test environment, I noticed that some security group rules were present even though the instances they applied to were not.

<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->

## 🧪 Testing

I modified the number of various instance types then executed `terraform plan` to validate that the corresponding security group rules were created/removed as expected.

boxes that apply. -->

pull_request.title: Upsize the Sidekiq Redis in staging.
pull_request.body:
- Use r6g.large (13 GiB) for staging instead of t4g.medium (3 GiB).
- Don't bother with standby instances in nonprod — not worth it at all. Offsets some of the cost of the bigger instance in staging.

This makes staging 50% the size of prod instead of ~10%, so it should serve as a more useful canary for some of the large one-off jobs that have been going on recently.

Already applied.

commits.body:
Accommodate larger Sidekiq queues in staging.

- Use r6g.large (13 GiB) for staging instead of t4g.medium (3 GiB).
- Don't bother with standby instances in nonprod — not worth it at all.

This makes staging 50% the size of prod instead of ~10%, so it should
serve as a more useful canary for some of the large one-off jobs that
have been going on recently.

pull_request.title: Manage team access to gov.uk repos using Terraform
pull_request.body:
This is currently a manual process and is frequently not done.

I split up the imports into 3 files to make it easier to review, we'll delete those files after applying the changes.

https://trello.com/c/tbQjgkwR/3249-automate-granting-team-access-to-govuk-tagged-repos-3
comments:
Hi Murilo - some comments below.

Also a note that we'll need to update [the Developer Docs](https://docs.publishing.service.gov.uk/manual/github.html#create-and-configure-a-new-gov-uk-repo) to direct people to add their repo to this list, as otherwise the automation won't happen. 

We'll also probably want a follow-on Trello card to check that repos in the Developer Docs also appear in this config (can add to the existing [verify repo tags script](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-saas-config/blob/main/.github/workflows/verify-repo-tags.yml).

PS: for the record, as Murilo noted on Slack, the [github-production Terraform Cloud](https://app.terraform.io/app/govuk/github-production/runs/run-RXUz8BYzEerGhTYy) result can be ignored as it will be removed, it is a temporary duplicate workspace (according to @marcpomfret).

Caught up with Murilo offline (more efficient!).

All of the 'imports' in this PR are a one-off, to get Terraform tracking all of the existing GOV.UK repositories' team access. If we skip the importing (as spiked in #943), [Terraform doesn't know about the teams](https://app.terraform.io/app/govuk/workspaces/GitHub/runs/run-VBVpFWVeAfZud2xW) and so treats them as brand new and with unknown properties until the 'apply' time:

> ![Screenshot 2023-09-12 at 16 52 39](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-infrastructure/assets/5111927/a926237e-2f1c-403f-be29-4a48ec098ede)

Whereas if we import the repos into Terraform as per this PR, [Terraform _does_ know exactly what needs to change](https://app.terraform.io/app/govuk/workspaces/GitHub/runs/run-ow91YLTVBYVrdyQD), i.e. just the team access:

> ![Screenshot 2023-09-12 at 16 52 44](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-infrastructure/assets/5111927/9bccb202-b9ec-4ddc-a630-bafda252a0ba)

Once the import has been run, we can then remove the import code.

Going forward, if a developer creates a new repo, the Terraform Plan/Apply should work just fine as-is. If the developer grants some manual team access, however, then they'd have to do this import hackery (or it would be easier to just remove the team access and let Terraform reapply it).

One small comment below about splitting out the commits for easier reversion later, but LGTM 👍

commits.body:
Manage team access to gov.uk repos using Terraform

This is currently a manual process and is frequently not done.

Import all existing resources

These will all be deleted once we apply these changes.

pull_request.title: Add Grafana Tempo for distributed tracing
pull_request.body:
This adds Terraform to deploy the Grafana Tempo helm chart (a distributed tracing tool) in to our EKS clusters. It has Terraform to create the relevant S3 bucket and IAM Role (used as the backing store).

Grafana Tempo integrates with our existing Grafana UI and is relative cheap/simple to run compared to other tracing tools (e.g. Jaeger/Zipkin/Sentry). Running it will allow us to better evaluate the value we get from tracing tools, and specifically if Tempo is the correct tool for us.

To send traces OpenTelemetry instrumentation need to be added/enabled to applications. We've shipped support for [OpenTelemetry instrumentation in govuk_app_config](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk_app_config/pull/303). This has been enabled and tested in integration.
comments: Cool!

commits.body:
Add S3 bucket and IAM Role for tempo

This adds the AWS resources need by Tempo. S3 is used as a backing store
and the IAM Role can be assumed by the service account to give it
permission to access the S3 bucket.

Add Tempo helm chart deployment

This adds Terraform to deploy the Tempo helm chart. We've enabled
persistent disk for the ingesters to prevent data loss if pods a
terminated. We've also enabled remote_write to Prometheus to allow Tempo
to add span metrics (allows us see which services are producing lots of
spans), and metrics are used to generate service graphs.

Ideally this chart should be deployed and managed by ArgoCD, but by having
everything in this Terraform file makes it easier to remove if we decide
against using Tempo.
Add Grafana datasource for Tempo

pull_request.title: Update kube-prometheus-stack and drop some unused high-cardinality metrics.
pull_request.body:
- Update kube-prometheus-stack to the latest minor release.
- Stop scraping kube-apiserver, which it turns out is surprisingly expensive and we were only doing because it's enabled by default in kube-prometheus-stack. We're not actually using any of those metrics.

```
k -n monitoring exec sts/prometheus-kube-prometheus-stack-prometheus -- \
    promtool tsdb analyze /prometheus
...
Highest cardinality metric names:
11682 apiserver_request_slo_duration_seconds_bucket
8015 http_request_duration_seconds
7992 router_backend_handler_response_duration_seconds_bucket
7510 apiserver_request_duration_seconds_bucket
6875 http_request_queue_duration_seconds
6844 container_memory_failures_total
5664 etcd_request_duration_seconds_bucket
4641 grpc_server_handled_total
4360 kube_pod_status_phase
4360 kube_pod_status_reason
3616 apiserver_response_sizes_bucket
```

Tested: applied in staging.

commits.body:
Update kube-prometheus-stack to latest minor release.

No incompatible changes.

Stop scraping kube-apiserver.

Turns out scraping the apiservers is surprisingly expensive and we're not
even using any of those metrics, so let's ditch it. This should make the
monitoring we do care about a bit more robust. We don't run the
apiservers anyway; that's in Amazon-land and there are metrics in
CloudWatch if we ever needed to look.

pull_request.title: Avoid logging healthcheck requests to Logit.
pull_request.body:
These are a non-negligible fraction of log traffic and they just clutter up query results (or complicate queries by trying to exclude them), so let's not pay for the inconvenience.

This won't stop us debugging healthchecks if we ever need to; it's easier to look directly at `kubectl log` etc. for that because it's real-time.

Also switch from the nasty HCL-encoded YAML to plain YAML for representing the Filebeat config. (Separate commit for ease of reviewing.)

Tested: applied in staging.

commits.body:
Use plain YAML for filebeat config.

This is so much easier to read and write than the HCL representation,
which has been making my head hurt the last couple of days.

We don't even need to refer to any HCL variables in this config file, so
it turns out to be trivial to switch to using its native representation
and still keep the ahead-of-time syntax checking.

The `yamlencode(yamldecode())` is not a no-op; we want the side effect
of it syntax-checking within Terraform at plan-time.

Tested: zero-diff in staging.

pull_request.title: Reduce Argo CD logspew + update to latest point release.
pull_request.body:
Argo CD notifications-controller and repo-server are quite noisy at `loglevel=info` and are the 9th and 10th noisiest workloads in the integration environment (19th and 20th in production). We don't need these info logs so let's not pay to store them. This should help towards getting us back under our log quota in LogIt.

Also set the log format to JSON so that the logs are easier to search.

Tested: running in integration.

commits.body: Update Argo CD from 2.7.4 to 2.7.6.

Reduce Argo CD log verbosity and log as JSON.

Argo CD notifications-controller and repo-server are quite noisy at
`loglevel=info`. We don't need these info logs so let's not pay to store
them. This should help towards getting us back under our log quota in
LogIt.

Also set the log format to JSON so that the logs are easier to search.

pull_request.title: Productionise Prometheus/Alertmanager config.
pull_request.body:
- Enable the kube-prometheus-stack chart's default PodDisruptionBudget for Prometheus and Alertmanager. The default is `minAvailable: 1`, which is fine.
- Set pod anti-affinity for Prometheus and Alertmanager so they can't end up with multiple replicas on the same node.
- Increase Prometheus metrics rentention from 10 days to 90 days and set the sampling (and eval) interval to 1 minute.
- Enable the use of ServiceMonitors and Probes in any namespace, like we already do for PodMonitors.
- Fix a weird variable name.

We only want PDB and anti-affinity where we're running more than one replica, i.e. in staging and production.

commits.body:
PodDisruptionBudget for Prometheus and Alertmanager.

Enable the kube-prometheus-stack chart's default PDB for Prometheus and
Alertmanager. The default is `minAvailable: 1`.
Set pod anti-affinity for Prometheus/Alertmanager.

Set scrape+eval intervals to 1m and increase retention.

1-minute sampling interval is perfectly adequate and allows us to retain
more history while making efficient use of resources.

Enable use of ServiceMonitors and Probes.

Configure Prometheus Operator to pick up ServiceMonitors and Probes in
any namespace, like we already do for PodMonitors.

Rename default_desired_ha_replicas to desired_ha_replicas.

Mostly generated with:

    git grep -l default_desired_ha_replicas |
        xargs gsed -i 's/default_desired_ha_replicas/desired_ha_replicas/'

commits.body:
Fix sizes of memcached and redis in prod.

EC2 prod has r6g.large for redis and r4.xlarge for redis. r6g is the
current generation equivalent (better performance for less $$$) and it's

equivalent of those since the beginning of govuk-on-k8s).

Enable multi-AZ for the redis cluster.

We have this enabled on the EC2 equivalent; must have been missed when
setting our one up.

pull_request.title: Give the EKS environment its own frontend memcache.
pull_request.body:
We can't share the Frontend memcache with the EC2 environments, because Frontend uses it to cache rendered HTML which contains links to Rails assets. My mistake 🤦

Also:

- Tweak the config for the shared Redis while we're there; it's very similar to the memcache one so let's make the two consistent.
- Remove the defaults for instance types and added those vars to the per-environment `.tfvars`, to make it less likely that we'll forget to set them appropriately when adding staging and prod.
- Hardcode the standard ports for Redis and memcached; we'd never want to run them on nonstandard ports so on balance it's cleaner to get rid of the module variable and save on interface clutter.
- Use a slightly smaller and cheaper instance type for Redis.
- Use provider default tags to simplify tagging the Redis cluster and associated resources. Saves the repeated boilerplate merge on every tagged resource.

Tested: applied successfully in the test account. Clusters/instances show up healthy in the AWS web console.
comments: Looks good, just some minor comments.

pull_request.title: Various fixes to external-dns configuration.
pull_request.body:
See commit messages for more details.

* Update the external-dns chart to the latest version.
* Use cluster ID for external-dns ownership record, not zone ID.
* Reduce external-dns's polling interval to 5m and enable watches, so that we don't blow through the 5 qps hard limit on Route53.

Rollout: requires deleting the A/TXT records in the external-dns-managed zone after deploying (so that external-dns recreates them with the new ownership details in the TXT records).

Tested: works in the test cluster; controller logs look good; records were recreated after deletion. Editing an Ingress triggered the reconciliation loop without waiting 5 minutes.

commits.body: Update Bitnami external-dns chart to the latest version.

Use cluster ID for external-dns ownership record, not zone ID.

Bitnami's example uses zone ID, but that doesn't actually make sense in
our case because it wouldn't prevent e.g. two clusters deployed in the
test account from fighting over records if they were both pointed at the
same zone. Using the cluster ID (cluster name) solves this and makes the
ownership records more understandable too.

Reduce external-dns's polling interval and enable watches.

The idea here is to reduce the QPS to Route53, since Route53 has a hard
limit of 5 QPS. The watches should be comparatively cheap as long as we
don't create an unreasonable number of Ingresses+Services (and we'd
almost certainly hit other scaling limits first anyway).

See https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/external-dns/blob/1b57fd7/docs/tutorials/aws.md#throttling
and https://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/DNSLimitations.html#limits-api-requests-route-53

pull_request.title: Naming and tagging improvements
pull_request.body:
* Add a workaround for the default tags not being applied to the cluster nodes and the managed node group ASG.
* Include the cluster name in all the resources created by the `cluster-infrastructure` module.
* Make it possible to pass in an alternative name for the cluster to the `cluster-infrastructure` module.

More detail in the commit messages.

I was resistant to the idea of using TF workspaces this time around, since the experience with the ECS project was rather expensive and painful - but having actually tried it, it's quite a bit simpler this time around. I've intentionally avoided any references to `terraform.workspace` in the code, because that was a significant factor in the testing/maintenance headache last time around.

Usage (for now) is like this:

```
tf workspace new $USER
tf apply \
        -var-file=../variables/test/common.tfvars \
        -var cluster_name=$USER
tf destroy \
        -var-file=../variables/test/common.tfvars \
        -var cluster_name=$USER
```

Once the VPC stuff is merged (and therefore the cluster has its own subnets), you'll also need a local vars file with a unique set of subnets so as not to overlap with the main test cluster (and can of course put the `cluster_name=$you` in there as well).

I propose that we don't continuously deploy anything other than the main (default) workspace; that's a big maintenance headache (not to mention significant AWS resource cost) and I don't think it provides any value since the CD pipeline itself is dead simple. Testing with tf init / plan / apply is sufficient for occasional TF changes when we don't want to take down the test cluster for whatever reason, and changes to the CD pipeline itself can just be tested on the test pipeline (which is really what it's for).

Tested: been running this for a couple of days now on a separate workspace. See below for TF plan (the `terraform-plan-cluster-infrastructure` check).

[Trello card](https://trello.com/c/mtzlqNa5/622)
comments: Looks good, just a question about whether we need to namespace the cluster-infra resources by workspace/cluster too.
Great work 🎉

commits.body:
Include cluster name in names of all managed AWS resources.

This allows for testing of breaking changes using workspaces.

Deliberately not including terraform.workspace anywhere in the config,
so as to avoid a repeat of the toil and complexity of the ECS TF codebase.
I wanted to have var.cluster_name default to the workspace name if
workspace!=default, but sadly this isn't possible in Terraform. (srsly?)
I also didn't want to introduce local.cluster_name because that's just
needlessly confusing.

So the way to use workspaces (on the hopefully-rare occasions that
they're needed) is:

    tf workspace new $USER

    tf apply \
        -var-file=../variables/test/common.tfvars \
        -var cluster_name=$USER

    tf destroy \
        -var-file=../variables/test/common.tfvars \
        -var cluster_name=$USER

Once the VPC stuff is merged (and the cluster has its own subnets),
you'll also need to define a local vars file with a unique set of
subnets so as not to overlap with the main test cluster.

Fix AWS tags for cluster nodes and node pool ASG.

This is a workaround for a couple of outstanding issues with the AWS
Terraform provider and the `eks` module, which were preventing default
tags from being propagated to the managed node group autoscale group.
Hopefully we'll be able to ditch the workaround at some point in future.
See the inline TODOs for details.

Also move root_volume_type into workers_group_defaults, since it makes
more sense there. (If we were to add another node group we'd want it to
default to gp3 storage and not the legacy, slightly pricier gp2 storage.)

pull_request.title: Provide Content Schemas to Publishing API in ECS
pull_request.body:
The Publishing API app depends on [content-schemas](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-content-schemas) being available at the path `/govuk-content-schemas`.

We use Capistrano to copy the content-schema files to EC2. As a temporary fix in ECS we have baked the content schemas into the publishing-api image. However, publishing-api releases should continue to be decoupled from content schemas versions in ECS.

In ECS we will push content-schemas to S3, trigger redeployments of publishing-api when new content-schemas versions are pushed to S3, and have publishing-api ECS Tasks copy content-schemas from S3 to the task file system for use by the publishing-api without requiring changes to the app.

This solution implements @karlbaker02's [design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nxJzdbTK__jWDFjUj9C5sH4yP0caIHhXp6fx1yKGHwE/edit) (internal-only).

Changes:

- Push content-schemas to S3 bucket in a Concourse job
- Updates to content-schemas triggers a deploy of publishing-api
- Publishing API can still be deployed without updating content-schemas
- Content Schemas will be deployed during bootstrapping but do not need to be deployed after every run-terraform job
- Added create-infrastructure job (inverse of destroy-terraform) to be run at 6am daily - triggers run-terraform, and enables us to run some jobs when bootstrapping but not on every run-terraform job.

The pipeline is available to view at https://cd.gds-reliability.engineering/teams/govuk-test/pipelines/deploy-apps-bill.
https://trello.com/c/6PvcoCAE/540-implement-content-schemas
comments: Very comprehensive, you've certainly gone to town on this. Great work! 🥳
Looks great Bill! 💯

commits.body:
Add content-schemas S3 bucket

The bucket is env and workspace aware.

Provide content-schemas to publishing-api at startup

When Publishing API ECS tasks startup, a transient volume will be
attached to the task (shared between tasks), and an init container
will be run before the app container is started.

The init container will copy the contents of the content-schemas
S3 bucket in the workspace to the path /govuk-content-schemas in
the volume.

The content schemas can be updated by redeploying publishing-api -
this is managed by Concourse (see prev commit).

Remove content schemas env var from frontend and content-store

Frontend uses the schemas in local tests. Content Store uses
the schemas in a rake task schema_validation:errors_for_format
- if this rake task is used we can add support for content-schemas.

pull_request.title: Upgrade terraform version to 0.15.5
pull_request.body:
This upgrades us from version 0.14.6 to the current version.

There are many minor improvements and bug fixes, nothing particularly notable for us. See the change log: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/blob/v0.15.5/CHANGELOG.md

Trello: https://trello.com/c/Ly0olSIz/531-upgrade-to-terraform-015
comments: One small comment, everything looks pretty sensible 🥇
LGTM, after discussing in more detail with Bill

commits.body:
Remove redundant comment

We've removed the v2 module

Specify complex collection type for dependsOn var

This was causing an error when planning Terraform
since upgrading from Terraform v0.14.6 to v0.15.5.

The error would manifest itself as:
element types must all match for conversion to list
when used in modules/task-definition/variables.tf:1,1-33.

As I understand it, every element in a Terraform list
must have a consistent type such as string, number
or a complex type like an object which has primitive
types for keys and vars like string.

If you use list(any) rather than list(object(full=detail))
Terraform will make assumptions of the list element
types, leading to the problem above.

If you explicitly state the types expected you can
avoid this problem.

Use complex type for container_definitions

This makes the container_definitions more robust by
specifying the values that will be accepted.

We'll be less likely to generate invalid task
definitions and errors will be clearer.

Stop using providers meta-argument for origin module

The origin module does not need us to set the meta-argument
providers [1].

The default behaviour is to inherit the root module's default
providers, i.e. all providers that aren't an alias.

We sometimes use the providers argument when we want to make
an alias provider such as aws.us_east_1 available to a module.
This isn't necessary here, since the origin module doesn't use
aws.us_east_1.

[1]: https://www.terraform.io/docs/language/meta-arguments/module-providers.html

Don't give providers to signon_bearer_token module

The default behaviour is to inherit the default providers,
so by ommiting the providers meta-argument we can do that.

Before upgrading to v0.15.5 I recall needing to use the
providers arg since it's in a for_each block. It looks
like it's not needed any more (it may never have been
needed!).

pull_request.title: Redeploy apps when secrets are rotated
pull_request.body:
Depends on https://github.com/alphagov/paas-s3-resource/pull/10
Trello: https://trello.com/c/LKgHd7ph/523-redeploy-apps-when-their-secrets-are-rotated

This adds an s3-iam resource that gives access to S3 buckets
in our AWS account (as opposed to the AWS account owned by
the team behind Big Concourse).

The frontend-deploy-event-trigger Concourse job will redeploy
the frontend app whenever a new object is placed in the frontend
bucket in `deploy-events-((workspace))`.

The intent is for the Secret Rotation Lambda to place a timestamped
file into the bucket whenever a secret an app uses is rotated,
triggering the app to be redeployed and the env var secrets for the
app's tasks to be refreshed from SecretsManager.

Screenshots:
-------------

Lambda places a file in an S3 bucket after rotating a secret:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8124374/120817344-8b94c780-c549-11eb-9100-bc267c6450b1.png)

Concourse resources checks for objects in the S3 bucket, triggering the deploy jobs:

![Screenshot 2021-06-04 at 15 47 21](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8124374/120820225-3efebb80-c54c-11eb-8567-8f90a9c9e73f.png)
comments: Looks good, a few small comments 🙂
Great work Bill! 🥇

commits.body:
Redeploy apps when secrets are rotated

This adds an s3-iam resource that gives access to S3 buckets
in our AWS account (as opposed to the AWS account owned by
the team behind Big Concourse).

The frontend-deploy-event-trigger Concourse job will redeploy
the frontend app whenever a new object is placed in the frontend
bucket in deploy-events-((workspace)).

The intent is for the Secret Rotation Lambda to place a timestamped
file into the bucket whenever a secret an app uses is rotated,
triggering the app to be redeployed and the env var secrets for the
app's tasks to be refreshed from SecretsManager.

pull_request.title: Autogenerate secret_key_base for Frontend app
pull_request.body:
Trello: https://trello.com/c/HQxqvue6/505-autogenerate-secretkeybase-when-bootstrapping

This autogenerates the `secret_key_base` secret for Rails apps (used for [cookie signing](https://edgeapi.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionDispatch/Cookies/ChainedCookieJars.html#method-i-signed)). This job is idempotent and will not attempt to create a secret if one already exists in SecretsManager.

I've started with the `frontend` app, it'll be trivial to update the other apps later.

See my pipeline for an example of this running: https://cd.gds-reliability.engineering/teams/govuk-test/pipelines/deploy-apps-bill.

commits.body:
Factor out secret_key_base data to separate file

This will make it easier to see which of these secrets
are still to autogenerate. It'll also remove stuff from
the overloaded secrets_manager file, which is just a list
of manually generated secrets.

Autogenerate frontend secret_key_base

This creates the secret for frontend's SECRET_KEY_BASE
environment variable. This replaces the data block that
pulls a secret that we manually inserted into Secrets Manager.

Later, I will add a commit that creates the initial secret value,
at the moment we just export the ARN which is all we'll need
to generate a secret and populate the version in Secrets Manager.

pull_request.title: Make Smokey workspace-aware
pull_request.body:
This ensures that the smoke tests are run for the correct workspace.

Currently it is possible for a workspace to run smoke tests for a different workspace.

Smoke tests currently have a single task definition family called 'smokey' unlike other task definition families such as 'frontend-bill' or 'publisher-ecs'.

As you can see, each pipeline will update the smoke tests with variables such as GOVUK_APP_DOMAIN - a workspace-aware domain such as bill.test. However, since the family is not workspace-safe, the smoke tests will simply run the tests for the workspace that last updated the smokey task definition.

This resolves the described problem by creating a smokey task family for each workspace.

Symptoms:

I discovered this when debugging why the smoke tests for the default workspace had failed. In the logs I found the error "You don’t have permission to sign in to [towers] Publisher" (raised when the smoke test user tried to login to Publisher in the `towers` workspace). This indicated that the smoke tests were using the wrong workspace.

commits.body:
Make Smokey workspace-aware

This ensures that the smoke tests are run for the correct
workspace.

Currently it is possible for a workspace to run smoke
tests for a different workspace.

Smoke tests currently have a single task definition
family called 'smokey' unlike other task definition
families such as 'frontend-bill' or 'publisher-ecs'.

As you can see, each pipeline will update the smoke
tests with variables such as GOVUK_APP_DOMAIN - a
workspace-aware domain such as bill.test. However,
since the family is not workspace-safe, the smoke
tests will simply run the tests for the workspace
that last update the smokey task definition.

This resolves the described problem by creating a
smokey task family for each workspace.

pull_request.title: Enable DynamoDB Terraform state locking
pull_request.body:
This enables locking on our Terraform state files.

The effect of this will be that one cannot perform concurrent operations on a Terraform statefile, such as applying and destroying concurrently.

https://www.terraform.io/docs/language/state/locking.html

You'll see an error when attempting to apply terraform if a lock has already been taken:

```
Error: Error locking state: Error acquiring the state lock: ConditionalCheckFailedException: The conditional request failed
Lock Info:
  ID:        12345
  Path:      govuk-terraform-test/env:/bill/projects/govuk.tfstate
  Operation: OperationTypeApply
  Who:       bill
  Version:   0.14.6
  Created:   2021-05-21 10:22:00.72746 +0000 UTC
  Info:      
```

https://trello.com/c/dR54Lh1c/518-enable-locking-on-our-terraform-statefiles

commits.body:
Enable DynamoDB Terraform state locking

This enables locking on our Terraform state files.

The effect of this will be that one cannot perform
concurrent operations on a Terraform statefile,
such as applying and destroying concurrently.

https://www.terraform.io/docs/language/state/locking.html

pull_request.title: Run Statsd as an ECS Service
pull_request.body:
This runs Statsd as an ECS service within the 'govuk' ECS cluster.

I've left the workspace out of the statsd namespaces for now, but we could add the workspace at the top level e.g. `govuk-<workspace>.app.<app_name>.ecs`.

Paired with @smford on this.
comments: Let's go with this and see how it pans out. Just a couple of trivial suggestions.

commits.body:
Add Statsd ECS Service

This recreates a Statsd ECS Service that we had during the discovery
phase of the project. We're going to get this Statsd instance
to send metrics to Graphite in EC2, so we don't need to recreate our
app metrics in Prometheus immediately.

Sadly App Mesh doesn't support UDP so we're still using TCP
to send metrics to Statsd.

This factors out the App Mesh and CloudMap resources into a
service-mesh-node module, and shares that module between statsd
and the app module. The intent is to make statsd not be treated
as an app, since it doesn't have a deployment requirement.

Enable apps to ship statsd metrics

This security group rule will permit Statsd to receive
metrics from any ECS Service created in the app module.

This also adds a security group which will be added to every
virtual service (ECS Service) in the service mesh (App Mesh).
This security group will be useful since we expect to have
multiple services that we wish most/all apps in ECS to send
requests to (statsd, prometheus) so this should reduce the
number of groups/rules we need to create.

Co-Authored-By: Bill Franklin <william.franklin@digital.cabinet-office.gov.uk>

Add Statsd environment variables to apps

Apps can configure the host and protocol of Statsd, and
the namespace for all metrics sent by the app via
environment variables set in this commit.

The namespace govuk.app.<app_name>.ecs will make it easier
to include ECS-sourced metrics in graphs and alerts in the
existing Grafana charts / Icinga alerts, since the format
for apps in EC2 is: govuk.app.<app_name>.<ip_address>,
which is used as (e.g.) govuk.app.<app_name>.*.<metric>
in Grafana.

pull_request.title: Grafana
pull_request.body:
As part of the [Observability epic](https://trello.com/c/tCpSuGiD/306-epic-observability), we spin up a Grafana instance in ECS to monitor GOV.UK ECS apps
and other components of the new platform e.g. billing.

## Features

1. Grafana spinned up in new cluster Monitoring to seperate concerns
2. Grafana is accessed via GitHub auth
3. Configuration of Grafana dashboards is via Terraform

## Testing

1. Grafana accessible via VPN at https://grafana-ecs.test.govuk.digital

## Deployment

Process is documented in docs/applying-terraform.md#monitoring

## Future Work

1. Subsequent apply of the terraform config for internal Grafana
configuration fails, workaround is documented in the deployment process.
2. Add teams to GitHub authorised users rather than the whole org
Alphagov
3. Deployment of the monitoring stack via Concourse

Ref:
1. [trello card](https://trello.com/c/RzaURJi5/323-set-up-a-grafana-in-ecs)
comments:
Nice work 👏 Thanks for adding documentation, too!

I've added some comments inline - let me know if you have any questions.

We don't need to separate the ECS Task Definition and ECS Service deployments for Grafana. We separate out the deployments for apps so we can hook into deploys and run steps like database migrations, but I'm not sure we need to do that in this case - it's just the app module pushes us to do it.

We could merge the deployments (`monitoring-test/grafana/base` and `monitoring-test/grafana/app-config`) for Grafana into a single deployment (perhaps `monitoring/grafana`) and remove a few files, [as with Statsd](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-infrastructure/pull/116). What do you think?

Fantastic 👍 You just have some conflicts.

I'm wondering if we could make the app module simpler by avoiding having grafana use it, but feel free to ignore that comment.

It might be nice to write followup cards to look into resolving some of issues we didn't get to (e.g. cycling grafana instances leads to grafana not being configured).

commits.body:
Add ECS Grafana

As part of the [Observability
epic](https://trello.com/c/tCpSuGiD/306-epic-observability),
we spin up a Grafana instance in ECS to monitor GOV.UK ECS apps
and other components of the new platform e.g. billing.

1. Grafana spinned up in new cluster Monitoring to seperate concerns
2. Grafana is accessed via GitHub auth
3. Configuration of Grafana dashboards is via Terraform

1. Grafana accessible via VPN at https://grafana-ecs.test.govuk.digital

Process is documented in [here](docs/applying-terraform.md#monitoring)

1. Subsequent apply of the terraform config for internal Grafana
configuration fails, workaround is documented in the deployment process.
Need to find way to persist grafana config
2. Deployment of the monitoring stack via Concourse

Ref:
1. [trello card](https://trello.com/c/RzaURJi5/323-set-up-a-grafana-in-ecs)

pull_request.title: Add a simple AWS billing dashboard
pull_request.body:
This is possible now that we've signed in to the root account and
enabled IAM users to view billing information :tada:.

This will hopefully give us a slightly easier-to-access view of our
billing (compared to having to sign in to AWS and look in
cost-explorer).

It's a bit naïve - CloudWatch's EstimatedCharges metric just increases
throughout the month and then resets. Might be nice to try to measure
the gradient, so we can see the rate we're spending at. But this
is good enough for now.

One interesting thing the graphs show is that the cost of the `test`
environment is still dominated by EC2 and RDS, even though we have quite
a bit of ECS stuff in there now. Not very scientific, but still.

Tested locally with docker-compose:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1696784/101629420-3acc6800-3a19-11eb-9051-67dfbeae7a0a.png)

commits.body:
Add a simple AWS billing dashboard

This is possible now that we've signed in to the root account and
enabled IAM users to view billing information :tada:.

This will hopefully give us a slightly easier-to-access view of our
billing (compared to having to sign in to AWS and look in
cost-explorer).

It's a bit naïve - CloudWatch's EstimatedCharges metric just increases
throughout the month and then resets. Might be nice to try to measure
the gradient, so we can see the rate we're spending at. But this
is good enough for now.

One interesting thing the graphs show is that the cost of the `test`
environment is still dominated by EC2 and RDS, even though we have quite
a bit of ECS stuff in there now. Not very scientific, but still.

Tested locally with docker-compose.

pull_request.title: Add deployment for draft content store
pull_request.body:
This makes it possible to deploy the draft content store.

Further work is required to deploy this application from Concourse.
comments: Thanks

commits.body:
Add deployment for draft content store

This makes it possible to deploy the draft content store.

Further work is required to deploy this application from Concourse.
Fixing Draft-content-store, Publishing-Api & Signon Workflow

Pin content store apps to bill-content-schemas

This image (see corresponding content store branch) contains
content schemas.

Output content store service security groups

This allows us to run ECS Tasks with the same security groups as the
deployed content store service.

Send Draft Content Store requests to Draft Router Api

This would usually be implemented via an environment variable read by
Plek PLEK_HOSTNAME_PREFIX but it is slightly clearer to have this
in Terraform.

Permit Draft Content Store to use EC2 MongoDB

This allows Draft Content Store to use the MongoDB cluster hosted in EC2
the same configuration as the Live Content Store, with a different database.

Permit Draft Content Store to receive reqs from Publishing API

The Publishing API sends requests to the Draft Content Store, in order to make
draft content available to the Draft Frontend application.

Content Store -> Router API ingress Security Group Rule

Content Store sends requests to Router API in ECS to publish routes.

Another security group is needed to allow Draft Content Store to send
requests to Draft Router API, when that app is brought up.

pull_request.title: Enable envoy access logs for all apps
pull_request.body:
As described in the AWS docs on AppMesh "Observability":

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/app-mesh/latest/userguide/observability.html

> When you send Envoy access logs to /dev/stdout, they are mixed in with
> the Envoy container logs. You can export them to a log storage and
> processing service like CloudWatch Logs using standard Docker log
> drivers such as awslogs. For more information, see Using the awslogs Log
> Driver in the Amazon ECS Developer Guide. To export only the Envoy
> access logs (and ignore the other Envoy container logs), you can set the
> ENVOY_LOG_LEVEL to off. For more information, see Access logging in the
> Envoy documentation.

It's possible that this approach would get expensive at
production-levels of traffic. I think it's worth doing for now though,
as it might help use troubleshoot issues while we're developing.

commits.body:
Enable envoy access logs for all apps

As described in the AWS docs on AppMesh "Observability":

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/app-mesh/latest/userguide/observability.html

> When you send Envoy access logs to /dev/stdout, they are mixed in with
> the Envoy container logs. You can export them to a log storage and
> processing service like CloudWatch Logs using standard Docker log
> drivers such as awslogs. For more information, see Using the awslogs Log
> Driver in the Amazon ECS Developer Guide. To export only the Envoy
> access logs (and ignore the other Envoy container logs), you can set the
> ENVOY_LOG_LEVEL to off. For more information, see Access logging in the
> Envoy documentation.

It's possible that this approach would get expensive at
production-levels of traffic. I think it's worth doing for now though,
as it might help use troubleshoot issues while we're developing.

### [`v3.0.0`](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​300-September-20th-2021)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/compare/v2.27.0...v3.0.0)

[2.x to 3.x upgrade guide](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/cloudflare/cloudflare/latest/docs/guides/version-3-upgrade)

BREAKING CHANGES:

-   resource/cloudflare_access_rule: `configuration` is now a `TypeList` instead of a `TypeMap` ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_custom_ssl: `custom_ssl_options` is now a `TypeList` instead of `TypeMap` ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_load_balancer: `fixed_response` is now a `TypeList` instead of a `TypeMap` ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_load_balancer: fixed_response.status_code`is now a`TypeInt`instead of a`TypeString\` ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_record: `data` is now a `TypeList` instead of a `TypeMap` ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))

NOTES:

-   provider: Golang version has been upgraded to 1.17 ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   provider: HTTP user agent is now "terraform/:version terraform-plugin-sdk/:version terraform-provider-cloudflare/:version" ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   provider: Minimum Terraform core version is now 0.14 ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   provider: terraform-plugin-sdk has been upgraded to 2.x ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))

ENHANCEMENTS:

-   resource/cloudflare_custom_hostname: `settings.ciphers` is now a `TypeSet` internally to handle suppress ordering changes. Schema representation remains the same ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_custom_hostname: `settings` is now `Optional`/`Computed` to reflect the stricter schema validation introduced in terraform-plugin-sdk v2 ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))
-   resource/cloudflare_custom_hostname: `status` is now `Computed` as the value isn't managed by an end user ([#​1188](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1188))

### [`v2.27.0`](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​2270-September-20th-2021)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/compare/v2.26.1...v2.27.0)

NOTES:

FEATURES:

-   **New Resource:** `cloudflare_access_keys_configuration` ([#​1186](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1186))
-   **New Resource:** `cloudflare_teams_account` ([#​1173](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1173))
-   **New Resource:** `cloudflare_teams_rule` ([#​1173](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1173))

ENHANCEMENTS:

-   resource/cloudflare_access_policy: add support for purpose justification and approvals ([#​1199](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1199))
-   resource/cloudflare_ruleset: add support for HTTP rate limiting ([#​1179](https://togithub.com/cloudflare/terraform-provider-cloudflare/issues/1179))

BUG FIXES:

pull_request.title: add `ci-pr` deployment
pull_request.body:
Hey,

This PR is intended to allow the [`prs` pipeline] to co-exist with
`nci` in the `hush-house` gke cluster.

it does so by:

- adding a node pool to the cluster (`ci-workers-pr`) whose size is the
  same as we had previously in our BOSH deployment
- adding a deployment (`ci-pr`) that puts workers in such node pool.

As such deployment is supposed to run untrusted workloads, we needed a
way of restricting the network access that this deployment could have in
order to avoid lateral movements in the internal net (in the case of our
BOSH environment, we had a totally different network - in k8s, we'd need
to be in a separate cluster if we wanted to go w/ the same approach of
different nets).

This led us to enabling the enforcement of network policies in the
cluster, and creating a policy for `ci-pr` that would target the pods
delpoyed by it, effectively blocking internal connectivity to anything
we didn't want (i.e., anything that's not ci's TSA).

ps.: these changes have already been applied.

[`prs` pipeline]: https://nci.concourse-ci.org/teams/main/pipelines/prs

related: https://github.com/concourse/prod/issues/36

commits.body:
terraform/deployments: add ci-pr workers

this commit is intended to allow the [`prs` pipeline] to co-exist with
`nci` in the `hush-house` gke cluster.

it does so by:

- adding a node pool to the cluster (`ci-workers-pr`) whose size is the
  same as we had previously in our BOSH deployment
- adding a deployment (`ci-pr`) that puts workers in such node pool.

As such deployment is supposed to run untrusted workloads, we needed a
way of restricting the network access that this deployment could have in
order to avoid lateral movements in the internal net (in the case of our
BOSH environment, we had a totally different network - in k8s, we'd need
to be in a separate cluster if we wanted to go w/ the same approach of
different nets).

This led us to enabling the enforcement of network policies in the
cluster, and creating a policy for `ci-pr` that would target the pods
delpoyed by it, effectively blocking internal connectivity to anything
we didn't want (i.e., anything that's not ci's TSA).

ps.: these changes have already been applied.

[`prs` pipeline]: https://nci.concourse-ci.org/teams/main/pipelines/prs

Signed-off-by: Denise Yu <dyu@pivotal.io>
Signed-off-by: Ciro S. Costa <cscosta@pivotal.io>
